blocks.html: In English, you might use the expression "you scared me to death!" In Chinese,  死了 (sǐ le) is used similarly to intensify an adjective with an unpleasant connotation.
The "Subject" part below is actually optional, you can still make your over-the-top exclamations without it.
This structure is technically a kind of degree complement.

children.english: I'm starving!
Today was so exhausting!
It's ridiculously hot!
It's been so terribly busy these days!
This clothing is totally hideous!
Your room is absolutely filthy!
It's so terribly noisy!
The things here are criminally expensive!
We are all so terribly anxious!
This kid is so freaking annoying!

blocks.html: None of these sentences actually refers to someone dying. Instead the word 死了 (sǐ le) and the structure is simply used to intensify an adjective. Notice how these are awkward to translate into English; the translations above took a number of different angles to create the same impact as -死了 (sǐ le) does in Chinese. You might say that -死了 (sǐ le) is much more versatile in Chinese than the English expression "to death."

Traditionally, -死了 (sǐ le) is only for adjectives with negative connotations, while positive connotations use a similar degree complement, 极了 (jí le). In recent years, however, it's become quite popular to also use -死了 (sǐ le) with positive adjectives:

children.english: OMG, adorbs!
Drop-dead gorgeous!
This cake is to die for!

差不多 (chàbuduō), translated literally, means "the difference is not much." In practice it means something like "more or less," and is useful for expressing rough approximations.
差不多 (chàbuduō) as a Predicate

As a predicate, 差不多 can be used pretty much all by itself to complete a sentence after you tell us what subject we're talking about. When several things are 差不多 (chàbuduō), it means they are "more or less the same." So actually 差不多 (chàbuduō) is often understood to mean 差不多一样 (chàbuduō yīyàng), but you don't say the 一样 (yīyàng) part. You just say 差不多 (chàbuduō).
Let's first assume that the subject is an easily understood group of people or things.
You might also add a 都 (dōu) in before 差不多 (chàbuduō) if there are more than two things being compared.

children.english: These places are all pretty much the same.
The meanings of these two words are pretty much the same.
Our ways of thinking are pretty much the same.
Those two restaurants' dishes are almost the same.
Your Chinese levels are almost the same.

blocks.html: Let's add in a few different subjects now, using the Chinese word for "and."

blocks.text: A + 跟 / 和 +  B + 差不多

children.english: Shanghai and New York are basically the same.
Starbucks and Costa are almost the same.
The weather here is pretty much like Taiwan's.
Your job and my job are almost the same.
Your new cell phone is pretty much like my old cell phone.

blocks.html: 差不多 (chàbuduō) as an Adverb
When using 差不多 (chàbuduō) as an adverb, place it before the adjective or verb.

children.english: These two children are more or less the same age.
My older brother and I are more or less the same height.
I'm almost at the entrance of the park.
The movie is almost about to start.
Today's work is almost done.

blocks.html: 差不多 (chàbuduō) with a Quantity or Time Phrase
blocks.text: 差不多 (chàbuduō) with a Quantity or Time Phrase

blocks.html: After 差不多 (chàbuduō) you can also add a phrase that expresses quantity or time. This makes it clear that you're giving a rough estimate.

children.english: Your son should be about 5 years old, right?
He has lived in Shanghai for about three months.
I've worked for this company for almost ten years.
My parents have been married for about twenty years.
About two weeks ago I met with him in Beijing.

title: Emphasizing quantity with "dou"
pattern: 大家 / 很多人 + 都⋯⋯

blocks.html: 都 (dōu) is one of those words that on the surface may seem simple, but actually has many different subtle uses. In this article, we will look at using 都 (dōu) to emphasize quantity.
You can use 都 (dōu) to emphasize the large quantity of something. The subject should be some sort of large group (like a majority of people or things), e.g. 很多人 (hěn duō rén) or 大家 (dàjiā).
Examples with 很多 (hěn duō)

First let's look at some typical examples using 很多 (hěn duō) to emphasize that it's "a lot." Note that in English, it would be totally redundant and unnecessary to add "all" into these sentences, but in Chinese it's totally natural (and kind of weird not to). If you remember to follow the rule and keep using the 都 (dōu), eventually it will become more natural for you too.

children.english: A lot of places have wifi.
A lot of my friends have cars.
A lot of Americans like drinking coffee.
A lot of kids don't like to go to school.
A lot of young people want to go to work in big cities.

blocks.html: Now let's look at some examples using 大家 (dàjiā) or "everyone." Again, in English, it would be totally redundant and unnecessary to add "all" into these sentences, but in Chinese it's totally natural (and kind of weird not to). You just have to get used to it.

children.english: Is everyone here?
Everyone should know.
Everyone says you're smart.
Everyone forgot his name.
Does everyone like eating spicy food?

blocks.html:
• 大家 都 来 了 吗？Dàjiā dōu lái le ma?Is everyone here?
  • 大家 都 应该 知道。Dàjiā dōu yīnggāi zhīdào.Everyone should know.
  • 大家 都 说 你 很 聪明。Dàjiā dōu shuō nǐ hěn cōngming.Everyone says you're smart.
  • 大家 都 忘 了 他 的 名字。Dàjiā dōu wàng le tā de míngzi.Everyone forgot his name.
  • 大家 都 喜欢 吃辣 吗？Dàjiā dōu xǐhuan chī là ma?Does everyone like eating spicy food?
Examples with 每天 (měi tiān)

One other common way to use 都 (dōu) is when you're talking about something that happens really often, such as "every day": 每天 (měi tiān).  Use 都 (dōu) here in Chinese, even if it feels unnatural. (Fake it 'til you make it!)

children.english: I have to go to work every day.
The teacher comes late every day.
Every day, she does not eat breakfast.

children.explanation: Taobao is China's biggest online shopping website.
children.english: My girlfriend goes on Taobao every day.
Mom cooks dinner for us every day.

blocks.html: For more uses with 每 (měi), see also: Expressing "every" with "mei".
Here are some other examples that don't use 很多 (hěn duō) or 大家 (dàjiā) or 每天 (měi tiān), but are still quite typical:

children.english: Americans all speak English.
All five of us are going.
Sichuanese people all like eating spicy food.
None of my family members has been to China.
My students all like to ask questions.

在 (zài) and 正在 (zhèngzài) can be used as auxiliary verbs to express that an action is ongoing or in progress. This is often the equivalent of present continuous in English, which is how we express that an activity is happening now.
You can use 正在 (zhèngzài) instead of just 在 (zài) to put a little more emphasis on an action that is in progress right now.

children.english: She is reading.
Mom is making a phone call.
Who is taking a shower in there?
The cleaning lady is cleaning our room right now.
Yesterday at 7pm, we were eating dinner.
The boss is currently in a meeting. He doesn't have time to see you.
I am working now. It's not convenient for me to leave.
We are in class right now; please wait a moment.
You're driving right now; you can't play with your cell phone.
When you called me, I was playing video games with friends.

blocks.html: There is no need to worry too much about when to use 在 (zài) or 正在 (zhèngzài), since they basically mean the same thing. 正在 (zhèngzài) usually shows that the action is in progress (right now). "在 (zài) + Verb" is more commonly used than "正在 (zhèngzài) + Verb," but both are fine to use.

一直 (yīzhí) literally means "straight." Used as an adverb, 一直 (yīzhí) can also be used to express that you have been doing something all along, have been continuously doing something since a certain time, or that something will continuously happen in the future.
This structure expresses the continuous nature of an action or a circumstance.
Also note that although 一直 (yīzhí) means "continuously," it is frequently more natural to use the word "always" in the English translation.

children.english: I've been studying Chinese all along.
Yesterday evening I was continuously doing homework.
The boss is always very busy.
I've always liked you a lot.
Dad has never smoked cigarettes.
My boyfriend has always been teaching English in China.
Since he was 18, he has always lived alone.
Have you always worked in this company?
Have you always been living together?
The air in Beijing has been bad for a while.

已经⋯⋯了 (yǐjīng... le) is the basic pattern used to express "already" in Chinese. It's easy to forget the 了 (le) on the end, but using it will make your Chinese more natural.
已经 (yǐjīng) with Verb Phrases
The most common structure is to use 已经⋯⋯了 (yǐjīng... le) with a verb phrase.

children.english: They've already left.
I already have a boyfriend.
The baby can already speak.
Mom has already come back.
He's already gotten on the plane.

blocks.html: Sometimes an adjective or a time noun is used instead of a typical verb phrase:

children.english: Mom and dad are already old.
It is already very cheap.
Your girlfriend is already very beautiful!
Is your cold already better?
It's already really late. Let's go.

blocks.html: 已经 (yǐjīng) with Time Nouns
A "time noun" simply refers to almost any word in Chinese indicating a time something happened.

children.english: It is already 11 o'clock, and my daughter has not returned.
Grandpa is already eighty-five years old.
I have already been studying Chinese for a year.
He has already been in the bathroom for half an hour.
It has already been two days since dad went to Beijing on business trip.

blocks.html: The negative structure simply adds a 不 (bù) after 已经 (yǐjīng), and before the verb (or possibly adjective).

blocks.text: 已经 + 不 + Verb + 了

blocks.html: Generally this negative 已经 (yǐjīng) structure is translated into English as "not... anymore" rather than using the word "already."

children.english: I don't like you anymore.
He doesn't love his cat anymore.
They don't live in China anymore.
I don't need my parents' money anymore.
You don't work at Google anymore?

If you are trying to describe a daily routine, a habit, or just something that consistently happens, you can use the word 总是 (zǒngshì). 总是 (zǒngshì) means "always," and like other adverbs, comes before the verb in a sentence.
总是 (zǒngshì) with Verbs
总是 (zǒngshì) is an adverb that is often translated to English as "always." It is placed before the verb that it modifies.

children.english: He is always late.
I always forget this word.
He always eats alone.
Your boyfriend always uses foul language.
My students always ask me lots of interesting questions.

blocks.html: When 总是 (zǒngshì) is used together with an adjective, you will need to add a modifier in the middle, such as 很 (hěn), 特别 (tèbié), 这么 (zhème), 那么 (nàme), etc.

children.english: He is always tired.
Why are you always very busy?
Your house is always very clean.
The children are always very happy.
My students are always very hard-working.

• 他 总是 很 累。Tā zǒngshì hěn lèi.He is always tired.
  • 你 为什么 总是 很 忙？Nǐ wèishénme zǒngshì hěn máng?Why are you always very busy?
  • 你 家 总是 很 干净。Nǐ jiā zǒngshì hěn gānjìng.Your house is always very clean.
  • 孩子们 总是 非常 开心。Háizi men zǒngshì fēicháng kāixīn.The children are always very happy.
  • 我 的 学生 总是 特别 努力。Wǒ de xuéshēng zǒngshì tèbié nǔlì.My students are always very hard-working.

In English we use "and also" when we want to connect separate and different thoughts. We can do the same thing in Chinese by using 还 (hái).
The adverb 还 (hái) can be used to link two phrases together, in a similar way to "and also" in English. In this case, 还 (hái) begins a new phrase or clause.

blocks.text: Subj. + Verb + Obj. 1， 还 + Verb + Obj. 2

children.english: She has a younger brother and also has a younger sister.
My boss can speak French and can also speak Japanese.
You want a cup of coffee, and what else do you want?
I want to eat ice cream and I also want to eat a hamburger.
Dad has a Xiaomi phone and also has an iPhone.
You did your homework at home tonight, and what else did you do?
When he got married, he invited his co-workers. Who else did he invite?
During a birthday, we eat cake and also give presents.
To go to the USA, you need to take money and a passport. What else do you need to take with you?

blocks.html: The Difference Between 还 (hái) and 也 (yě)
blocks.text: The Difference Between 还 (hái) and 也 (yě)

blocks.html: It should be noted that another common way to express "also" is with the word 也 (yě). What's the difference? With 还 (hái), ONE subject is doing TWO different things, whereas when 也 (yě) is used, TWO subjects are doing ONE thing.
It's the difference between these two English sentences:

• He fixed dinner and also washed the dishes.
  • She washed the dishes too.
If you translated these into Chinese, the first one (one subject, two actions) would use 还 (hái), and the second one (second subject, no new actions) would use 也 (yě). Let's do that!

children.english: He fixed dinner and also washed the dishes.
She washed the dishes too.

blocks.html: How about a few more similar examples?

children.english: I took a shower and also did my laundry.
She did her laundry too.
We went out for dinner tonight and also watched a movie.
They watched a movie tonight too.

blocks.html: For events that happened in the immediate past, in English we use the word "just." For example, if you pass a turn you were supposed to make, you might say, "I just passed it!" In Chinese, "just" can be expressed with 刚 (gāng) or 刚刚 (gānggāng).
刚 (gāng) expresses an action that happened not long ago. 刚刚 (gānggāng) is used the same way, with the same meaning.

children.english: We just found out.
They just left.
The boss just arrived at the office.
My wife just finished giving birth to our baby.
Did you just get off work?

blocks.html: "Just" Within a Specific Time Period
This more complicated use of 刚 (gāng) is not nearly as essential as the one above, but you may find it useful to specify just when the event "just" occurred, specifically.
刚 (gāng) can also express "from the time an action happens until the present time."
Note that although we need to say "ago" in English, in this pattern there's no need for a word that means "ago."

children.english: I just met her ten days ago.
He just got to China two months ago.
My younger brother just started working half a year ago.
She just got married three months ago.
I just bought the car two days ago. Be careful when you drive.

There are a number of different ways to express "only" in Chinese, but 只 (zhǐ) is the most basic one you need to learn first. It's an adverb, so it normally comes before verbs.
The adverb 只 (zhǐ) can come directly before a verb, or before an auxiliary verb like 会 (huì) or 能 (néng).

We only have ten RMB.
Our company only has two employees.
Do you only like eating meat?
They can only speak English.
I can only say two sentences in Chinese.
Do you only want coffee?
My wife only wants one child.
The baby can only walk. He can't run.
I only want to be with you.

The adverb 就 (jiù) has quite a few uses in Chinese, and appears in several common patterns. This is the first and simplest usage you need to know, though, and it means something similar to "then."
Usually the first part of the sentence will set up a situation. Then the second part, with 就 (jiù) leading the way, indicates what should be done as a result.
Not always easy to translate, you could think of 就 (jiù) as meaning "just" or "then."

children.english: So you like milk tea. Then we'll buy milk tea.
You have the most experience. We'll just listen to you.
As soon as I heard this bad news, I called you.
Your health isn't good now. So just stop drinking.
He's been too tired recently, and then he got sick.
It's going to rain today. So let's just not go out.
His mom didn't buy him the backpack, and then he just started crying.
Let's just eat at this restaurant. That one is too crowded.
Let's just go watch a movie.

title: Simultaneous tasks with "yibian"
pattern: 一边 + Verb 1 (，) 一边 + Verb 2

blocks.html: Multitasking is everywhere in the modern world (what else are you doing while you read this?), but you if can focus for just a minute, you can learn a way to express simultaneous tasks in Chinese! This can be done with 一边 (yībiān).
To express that one thing is done while doing something else, the word 一边 (yībiān) is used.

blocks.text: Subj. + 一边 + Verb (，) + 一边 + Verb

blocks.html: Note that you sometimes see 一边 (yībiān) shortened to 边 (biān) as well, which has a less formal feel.

children.english: Don't speak while eating.
I often sing songs while I take a shower.
Children like to play while eating.
Do you like to listen to music while doing homework?
Let's walk while we talk.
Please write as you read.
Don't talk on the phone while you drive.
The boss likes to smoke while working.
Many people play with their cell phones while working.
She often looks after the baby while cooking food.

blocks.html: You'll notice that the order of the two actions is sometimes different in the original Chinese and the English translations above. This is because the "main" action usually comes second in English (after the "while"), but first in Chinese. For example, "take a shower while singing" sounds strange in English, but "sing while taking a shower" doesn't.

Note that you must be actively doing both actions. That is, they have to be intentional. If you want to say something happened while another thing was happening, it would be better to use 的时候 (de shíhou).

How big? How busy? How cold? Ask questions like these regarding the degree of an adjective with 多 (duō). This is just one of the many uses of this word.
多 (duō) is often used to ask about the degree or extent of something.
This is an easy way to ask "How [adjective] is [subject]?"

children.english: How tall is she?
How large is your house?
How old is your child?
How long is the Yellow River?
How far is your house away from here?
How long are you going to stay in the USA?
How heavy are these things?
Do you know how fat we are now?
Do you know how cold it is here in winter?
Do you know how expensive housing is in Shanghai?

blocks.html: 大 (dà) and 小 (xiǎo) can also be used to describe ages. The question phrase 多大 (duō dà) is often used to ask "how old." However, it is an informal way to ask, usually reserved for peers, close friends, or children. The phrase 几岁 (jǐ suì) is most often used for children young enough to display their ages on one hand. Adults do not normally directly ask each other's ages in a formal setting.

title: Basic comparisons with "yiyang"
pattern: Noun 1 + 跟 / 和 + Noun 2 + 一样 + Adj.

blocks.html: Along with 比 (bǐ) and 没有 (méiyǒu), 一样 (yīyàng) is another way to make basic comparisons. However, 一样 (yīyàng) is used to express that two things are the same in some way.
This simple structure is used for stating that two things are the same:

blocks.text: Noun 1 + 跟 / 和 + Noun 2 + 一样

children.english: I am the same as you.
He has the same personality as his mom.
The weather in Beijing and the weather in Shanghai are not alike.
Are the meanings of this word and that word the same?
American culture and Chinese culture are not the same.

blocks.html: To add an adjective into the mix, just place it after 一样 (yīyàng):

blocks.text: Noun 1 + 跟 / 和 + Noun 2 + 一样 + Adj.

blocks.html: This describes Noun 1 as being as adjective as Noun 2.

children.english: Your house is just as big as mine.
She and her older brother are equally tall.
You hair is as long as mine.
The weather here is just as comfortable as my hometown's.
Are you as busy as the boss is?

blocks.html: There is also a similar but more advanced usage of this pattern that uses 像 (xiàng).

At times you may want to politely diss something using the phrase "a little too."  For example, if you are getting lunch with a friend who wants to be seated outside, you might say, "It is a little too hot" to suggest you sit inside. In a case like this, you can use 有一点 (yǒuyīdiǎn) or 有点 (yǒudiǎn). The two are interchangeable.
To say that something is "a little too..." or "a bit too...," 有一点 (yǒuyīdiǎn) is often used. Its northern Chinese version is 有一点儿 (yǒuyīdiǎnr).
In spoken Chinese, the 一 (yī) in 有一点 (yǒuyīdiǎn) is often dropped, leaving 有点 (yǒudiǎn).  In northern China, that's usually pronounced 有点儿 (yǒudiǎnr).

children.english: I'm a little hungry.
This dish is a little too spicy.
Yesterday it was a little too hot.
Winter in Shanghai is a bit too cold.
My younger brother is a bit fat.
Today I am a little bit tired.
This month the company is a little bit busy.
This place is a little too noisy. Let's go.
Dad came back home a bit too late, so mom was a little unhappy.
Today, the teacher felt a little unwell, so she didn't come to class.

blocks.html: Note that for the speaker, the adjective after 有点 (yǒudiǎn) expresses an unpleasant or undesirable meaning, so you won't hear things like 有点高兴 (yǒudiǎn gāoxìng), 有点舒服 (yǒudiǎn shūfu), 有点好玩儿 (yǒudiǎn hǎowánr), etc., because "happy," "comfortable," and "fun" are all adjectives with positive connotations.

Your boss is both young and rich.
The coffee here is both expensive and bad-tasting.
My family's dog is both cute and obedient.
Winter here in Shanghai is both cold and humid.
She was both short and thin when she was young.

title: Expressing distance with "li"
pattern: Place 1 + 离 + Place 2 + Adv. + 近 / 远

blocks.html: Are we there yet? One of the ways to express distance is to use 离 (lí). The word order might seem a little tricky at first, but once you get it down, you'll be able to talk about distance with no problem.
Using 离 (lí) in a Statement
Unless you're talking about a very specific distance, you'll normally want to pair 离 (lí) with the adjective 近 (jìn) for "close," or 远 (yuǎn) for "far."

blocks.text: Place 1 + 离 + Place 2 + Adv. + 近 / 远

blocks.html: So this pattern is normally used to simply express that one place is (not) close or (not) far from another place. Easy, right? It's learning the sentence pattern that usually trips learners up, because it doesn't feel like natural word order to a speaker of English.

children.english: My house is close to my office.
The USA is far from China.
This hotel is very close to the train station.
That bar is too far away from here. I don't want to go.
I don't want to go work at a place very far away from home.

blocks.html: Using 离 (lí) in a Question
These two sentence patterns are extremely common in everyday conversations when discussing distances.

blocks.text: Place 1 + 离 + Place 2 (+ Adv.) + 近 / 远 + 吗？
Place 1 + 离 + Place 2 (+ 有) + 多远？

blocks.html: Note that in English, you can actually ask, "How close is it from here?" if the distance is obviously short. But in Chinese it's just, "How far is it from here?"

children.english: Is your house far away from the supermarket?
Is your college very far away from your hometown?
Is your company close to the metro station?
How far is it from your home to school?
How far is it from this hotel to the airport?

blocks.html: Expressing "Stay Away from Me" with 离 (lí)
blocks.text: Expressing "Stay Away from Me" with 离 (lí)

blocks.html: One final example is a command, commonly heard in colloquial Chinese:

children.english: Stay away from me.

blocks.html: It's a somewhat atypical usage when compared with the others, because it uses two people rather than two places. The sentence literally means, "Distance yourself from me further." In other words, "Stay away from me," or "Don't come near me."

To express "even more," (as in "even more expensive," "even more ridiculous," "even more badass"), you can use 更 (gèng). 更 (gèng) generally comes before adjectives.
The pattern in Chinese is simple:

Note that this pattern is not simply a way of adding "-er" to an adjective or a substitute for 比 (bǐ) comparisons. In each case, you're adding "even more" to an existing considerable amount, as in, "I'm already rich, but I want to be even richer."

children.english: Between these two banks, which one is closer?

children.explanation: It is implied that my boyfriend now is already handsome, but I want to find an even more handsome boyfriend.
children.english: I want to find a more handsome boyfriend.
I like buying books online because it's cheaper.

children.explanation: It is implied that a lot of work has already been done but there is still "even more" work left.
children.english: Don't get too excited. We still have more work to do.
She's become more beautiful after she got married.

blocks.html: While 更 (gèng) is not a substitute for 比 (bǐ) (the classic comparison word), the two can be used together.

blocks.text: A 比 B + 更 + Adj.

blocks.html: This expresses that "A is even more Adj. than B."

children.english: The houses in Beijing are even more expensive than those in Shanghai.
Spring Festival is even more boisterous than Mid-autumn Festival.
Chinese characters are even more difficult than tones.
His current girlfriend is even more beautiful than his previous one.
China's high-speed trains are even more convenient than airplanes.

You may be familiar with using 太 (tài) to express "too," such as when something is "too expensive" or "too hot." 不太 (bù tài) is a similar pattern for the negative, which just means "not very" or "not so" (literally "not too"). Note that this pattern does not normally use 了 (le).
不太 (bù tài) with Adjectives
Note: This pattern can also be used with non-adjectives.  See below for more info.

children.english: My house is not too big.
That place is not very far away.
The boss is not very happy today.
The clothes in this shop are not too expensive.
I think he is not too smart.

children.english: I don't really understand.
I can't really speak English.
They don't really want to go.
My older brother doesn't really like his job.
He didn't really understand what the boss meant.

As an adverb, the word 真 (zhēn) means "really" or "truly."
真 (zhēn) is used only in exclamatory sentences and comes before an adjective.

children.english: You are so nice!
Your girlfriend is really pretty!
His family is really rich!
This puppy is really cute!
It's truly hot today!

children.english: Your mother really loves you!

One way to intensify a sentence is to make it an exclamation. To do this, you can use 多 (duō).
As well as asking about degree, you can also use 多 (duō) to intensify adjectives.

children.english: It's so nice being alone!
Your daughter is so smart!
Today's weather is so nice!
Look at this place, it is so beautiful!
Studying Chinese is so interesting!
How convenient it is to take the metro!
Look at this puppy! It is so cute!
Doing it this way is so troublesome!
These foods are so delicious!
Your boyfriend is so handsome!

blocks.html: 多 (duō) can be compared to 很 (hěn) in this case. If you use 很 (hěn) instead of 多 (duō), the meaning is basically the same. However 很 (hěn) is also used to make simple "noun + adjective" sentences, which might not be exclamatory at all, whereas 多 (duō) is used only for excited exclamations.

Whenever you want to imply that something is "good," but also kind of "meh," you can use 还 (hái) in front of the "good" adjective.

Besides expressing continuation, 还 (hái) can also be used to weaken positive adjectives. Used with the adjective "good," this is similar to saying "fairly good" or "pretty good" in English. It's also sometimes used by a speaker to be more modest. Below are some of the most common adjectives that get "toned down" by 还 (hái) in this structure.

blocks.text: Subj. + 还 + 好 / 可以 / 行 / 不错

blocks.html: In this pattern, 好 (hǎo), 可以 (kěyǐ), 行 (xíng), and 不错 (bùcuò) combined with 还 ()hái can all be taken to mean "pretty good" or "all right" or "decent" (but also kind of meh... not great). As in English, intonation and facial expressions help convey the meaning. If expectations were already low to begin with, 还可以 (hái kěyǐ) can have the sense of "pretty darn good;" it all depends on context and tone of voice.

children.english: I'm OK.
The food that dad cooks is OK.
Our boss is not too bad.
This shop is OK. It's not too expensive.
My boyfriend's salary is OK.
The new office is OK.
I think the food here is OK, it is not too bad-tasting.
This brand is not too bad. Many young people like it.
The apartment is not too bad, but it is a bit expensive.

One of the best ways to use the common character 的 (de) is to spice up your nouns with adjectives. By using 的 (de), we can connect sassy adjectives to otherwise boring nouns.
A very common way to modify nouns is to attach an adjective to them using 的 (de).

This structure comes up extremely frequently and is an easy way to attribute features to nouns. Occasionally you will see this 的 (de) omitted, but note that if the adjective has two characters (e.g. 漂亮 (piàoliang) or 高兴 (gāoxìng)), the 的 (de) is generally required.

children.english: beautiful girl
spicy food
a cute baby
I like fresh fruit juice.
He often buys cheap stuff.

blocks.html: In some cases, it is possible to drop the noun from the pattern, and just use the adjective + 的 (de). This is kind of like saying "the big one" or "the red one" in English. In Chinese the 的 (de) serves the same purpose as the English word "one." By using this pattern, you can avoid repeating the same noun over and over again unnecessarily. Just be sure the other person is already clear which "one" you're referring to when using this pattern!

In addition to linking adjectives to nouns, 的 (de) can also be used to link a whole phrase to a noun, making the already useful 的 (de) even more useful.

As well as attaching adjectives to nouns, 的 (de) can be used to attach whole phrases to nouns. In English this is often achieved with "who" or "that." For example, "the man who went to Beijing" or "the book that I bought yesterday."
Here the phrase is typically of the form "Noun + Verb." The pattern, by itself, doesn't make clear whether the action happened in the past, present, or future.

children.english: the food that mom cooks / cooked
the train that goes / went to Beijing
the students that you teach / taught
the friends that the boss invites / invited
the pictures that I draw / drew
the books that he wrote
the clothes that mom buys / bought for me
the questions that the client asks / asked
women who wear / wore Prada
the foreigners that don't / didn't like Chinese food

blocks.html: In some cases, it is possible to drop the noun from the pattern, and just use the "Noun + 的 (de)." This is kind of like saying "what Mom made" or "the red one" in English. In Chinese the 的 (de) serves the same purpose as the English word "what." By using this pattern, you can avoid repeating the same noun over and over again unnecessarily. Just be sure the other person is already clear about the "what" you're referring to when using this pattern!
Note that for certain phrases, it may be ambiguous what the "what" refers to, and sometimes it could even refer to a "who."

children.english: what mom cooks / cooked
what I draw / drew
what he writes / wrote

The most common way to form a superlative (best, worst, biggest, smallest, etc.) in Chinese is to use 最 (zuì) before an adjective (and a few select verbs).

And now you have the superlative form of the adjective. Unlike in English, this structure is consistent for all adjectives in Chinese. The inconsistencies in English sometimes confuse beginners, so note in the examples below how to say "best," "worst," "least," and "most" (meaning "greatest number").

children.english: Which teacher is the best?
In your family who is the most beautiful?
Who is the richest?
The Chinese language is the most difficult.
These kind of things are the most troublesome.

blocks.html: Occasionally you'll also see a 了 (le) added after the adjective.  This simply adds emphasis to the "-est."

children.english: The puppy is the cutest.
Sichuan food is the spiciest.
My Chinese friend is the most enthusiastic.
His student is the most serious.
Huang Mountain's landscape is the most beautiful.

blocks.html: 最 (zuì) can also come before psychological verbs, to express what one "most likes," "most hates," etc. It won't make sense if you try to use 最 (zuì) with non-psychological verbs, though.
Note the 了 (le) on the end there! It's not strictly required, but you'll hear it a lot in spoken Chinese.

children.english: The boss likes you the best!
What do you most fear?
I love Chinese food most.
Who knows you best?
She most hates men that smoke.

blocks.html: Although you could translate it as "like the best," pairing 最 (zuì) with the psychological verb 喜欢 (xǐhuan) is also a great way to talk about one's "favorite."

children.english: What is your favorite color?
What is your favorite animal?

Using 跟 (gēn) to express "with" is so simple and helpful, after studying it briefly, it will always be with you! 跟 (gēn) is a very common word that will help complete many other sentence structures.
The preposition 跟 (gēn) is commonly used to express "with." Just remember that the "with" phrase comes before the verb.
The word 一起 (yīqǐ) is used a lot with 跟 (gēn), expressing the idea of "doing something together with somebody." It may seem kind of redundant, but it's totally normal in Chinese to use both.
Also, for most of the examples below, 跟 (gēn) is interchangeable with 和 (hé), which you may remember, also means "and," just like 跟 (gēn) does.

blocks.text: Subj. + 跟 + Person + 一起 + Verb + Obj.

blocks.html: Certain Chinese verbs use 跟 (gēn) a lot, so be on the lookout for them (examples below)!

children.english: I went to the beach with friends yesterday.
Don't talk to me!
I'm going to meet new clients tomorrow.
When are you gonna marry your girlfriend?
Do you like to talk with your parents?
Do you want to go with me?
Please read together with the teacher.
Who is going on a business trip together with the boss next week?
Do you want live together with your parents after you get married?
Are you going to spend this Mid-Autumn Festival with your family?

blocks.html: Note: One of the most common beginner mistakes is to fail to use 跟 (gēn) with 见面 (jiànmiàn), "to meet." It might help to think of 见面 (jiànmiàn) as "to meet with (somebody)," the "with" cluing you into the fact that you need a 跟 (gēn) in there. The verbs 结婚 (jiéhūn), "to marry," and 聊天 (liáotiān), "to chat" are used with 跟 (gēn) in the exact same way.

children.english: I want to meet with you.
I met with him yesterday.
When are you going to meet with her?
Tomorrow I am going to meet my boyfriend's family.
Have you ever met Obama?

blocks.html: Later on you'll learn more about why this is the case, but for now just memorize the correct pattern.
Where 和 (hé) and 跟 (gēn) Differ
blocks.text: Where 和 (hé) and 跟 (gēn) Differ

blocks.html: We mentioned earlier that 跟 (gēn) is essentially interchangeable with 和 (hé).  There's at least one common usage where this is not the case, though:

children.english: Read after me.

blocks.html: The reason is that although 跟 (gēn) and 和 (hé) can both mean "and" or "with," the word 跟 (gēn) also has a sense of "to follow" embedded in it. There's a before/after aspect.
The following sentences are both correct, because they're simultaneous rather than before/after:

children.english: Read with me.

blocks.html: Because of this slight difference between 跟 (gēn) and 和 (hé), it's recommended to start out using 跟 (gēn) to mean "with."

In conversation, you may find yourself at a loss for words, unable to find the correct phrase you are looking for, or simply needing time to gather your thoughts. When you experience this feeling, in English, you may say "umm" or "uhhh" or another filler word. In Chinese, the word for this is 那个 (nèige). (The word 那个 can be pronounced both "nàge" and "nèige," but for this usage, "nèige" is normally used.)

In English, words like "ummm" and "uh" are used as filler words when you're thinking about what to say. In Chinese, 那个 (nèige) is also used for this purpose. To English speakers not fortunate enough to be fluent in Mandarin this may raise an eyebrow because it can sound a bit "racist," but it's very common in Mandarin and you'll hear it quite often around Chinese speakers.
那个 (nèige) can be inserted into sentences wherever you need to pause for thought.

children.english: So, ummm... I won't go with you guys, OK?
I want to eat that... ummm, you know... Hunan cuisine.
Ummm... I'm not coming tomorrow.
Ummm, it's not good to do it this way?
Like... could you be my girlfriend?
Ummmm... sorry, but I've gotta go.
She's very pretty, just like, you know, a celebrity.
I'd like to take a look at your, ummm, you know... iPhone you bought.
Ummm... I have to attend a meeting.
Yesterday the, you know, steamed soup dumplings were so delicious.

blocks.html: Using "but" in Chinese is really simple to learn. It involves the two words 可是 (kěshì) and 但是 (dànshì). Make no "buts" about it; you'll understand it in no time!

There are two main words for "but" in Chinese: 可是 (kěshì) and 但是 (dànshì). These are largely the same.  The small difference is that 但是 (dànshì) is slightly more formal, whereas 可是 (kěshì) is just a bit more informal and a tad weaker in tone.  You really don't need to worry about which one is the right one to use though, since they can be used interchangeably.

blocks.text: Statement， 可是 / 但是 + [Contrary Statement]

blocks.html: Usually 可是 (kěshì) and 但是 (dànshì) precede a new phrase within a sentence:

children.english: I like him, but he doesn't like me.
I really want to go, but I am too busy.
Chinese is very interesting, but it is also very hard.
I like this shirt, but it is too expensive.
The boss gave him a call yesterday, but he didn't answer.
The iPhone is great, but I don't have the money to buy it.
You can read books here, but you can't talk.
You can eat, but you can't eat too much.
He said he would come to see me at five, but he didn't.
This place is beautiful, but there are too many people.

blocks.html: Note: In informal spoken Chinese, 可是 (kěshì) can be shortened to 可 (kě), and 但是 (dànshì) can be shortened to 但 (dàn).

Just as 以前 (yǐqián) can be used to describe the events before a specific time, 以后 (yǐhòu) can be used to describe the events after a specific time.
This grammar structure is similar to the English "after such-and-such, something happens." It's quite simple, all you have to do is put the "after" after the time words or time phrase.
The time can be a time or date, or an action or event. It may or may not be in the future.

children.english: After three p.m., I will not be at home.

After one month, she will start working.
We are going to have a meeting after we finish lunch.
In a few years, our company will be even bigger.
After half an hour, the boss will return.
After we get off work, would you like to go play ball with us?
After the boss came, everyone stopped talking.
After you get home, call me.
After he got married, dad stopped drinking.

In order to say that something "just now" occurred, use the time noun 刚才 (gāngcái). It can be placed in front of the verb or the subject of a statement.
This grammar structure is pretty straightforward. Similar to the English "just now," you can put 刚才 (gāngcái) right before the verb in a sentence. It can also come before or after the subject.

children.english: What did you just say?
Who came just now?
Where did you go just now?
I just went to the restroom.
The boss just got angry.
What were you looking at just now?
I'm sorry, I just now stepped out.
The baby just cried.
They just went to a meeting.
Just now, there was someone looking for you.

blocks.html: Note that for all of those cases, we're talking about something that happened just now, as in, within the past 5 minutes or so. If you're talking about something that "just happened" yesterday or last week, don't use 刚才 (gāngcái), use 刚 (gāng).

The manner in which large numbers are broken down in Chinese is a little different from English. Unlike in English, where large numbers are broken down by the number of thousands they have, Chinese forms numbers between 10,000 and 100,000,000 based off of how many tens of thousands they have (with another set of rules for numbers 100,000,000 onwards that will be explained later). While the structure can be difficult to grasp for some learners, there are some easy ways to remember how to form these big numbers.
Mandarin has two units that English doesn't have (or at least, it has unique words for these units, whereas English describes them with combinations of other units). These are:

万 (wàn) comes up the most often and is the largest stumbling block for most people learning Mandarin numbers. In English, numbers are usually broken up into chunks of three digits. Because of 万 (wàn), it's easier to break numbers up into groups of four in Mandarin. In English, we split "twelve thousand" numerically into "12,000" (chunks of three digits). Split it the Chinese way, "1,2000," and the Chinese reading "一万两千" (one wan and two "thousand" = yīwàn liǎngqiān) makes more sense.

One way to remember how to write out numbers 10,000 through 99,999 in Chinese characters is that in Chinese, the comma is (mentally) moved one digit to the left. For example, 11,000 could be thought of in tens of thousands as "1,1000," with 万 (wàn) replacing the comma, and then what's left written as 一千 (yīqiān): 一万一千 (yīwàn yīqiān).

After 99,999,999, there is yet another new numerical unit, 亿 (yì), which is used to express "hundred million." A number like 1,101,110,000 would be written out as "十一亿一百一十一万 (shíyī yì yībǎi yīshí-yī wàn)." Again, an easier way to translate between the two methods is to write the number out in English, move the comma one digit to the left, and then insert the appropriate characters in their respective places, replacing the commas.

If you can memorize that, then going to 一千万 (yīqiān wàn) is way easier and faster, since you don't have to count all those zeroes.

If you already know the basics of how to tell time in Chinese, you may want to get a little more specific or sophisticated, using words like 分 (fēn) and 刻 (kè).
Minutes are marked with 分 (fēn) (short for 分钟 (fēnzhōng)). The way to include them in the time depends on whether they're minutes past or to the hour.
Minutes past the hour are expressed after 点 (diǎn) in the same way as half and quarter hours.

In Chinese, when the minute is under 10, the word 零 (líng) is often used after 点 (diǎn). For example, 2:07 would be said as “两点零七分” (liǎng diǎn líng qī fēn). However, note that when speaking, it is very common for most Chinese people take out the “分 (fēn)” at the end of the time.

blocks.text: x 点 零 y 分

blocks.html: There's nothing tricky about this, since there's no 零 (líng). Just remember that in casual speech, the 分 (fēn) at the end is sometimes dropped.

In Chinese, quarter hours are only expressed on the 1st quarter x:15, and the third quarter x:45. Like half hours, they also come after the word 点 (diăn). We use the word 刻 (kè) to express "quarter hour."
You can totally just use 十五分 (shíwǔ fēn) for "15 minutes (past)" or 四十五分 (sìshí-wǔ fēn) for "45 minutes (past)" if you're lazy, though. It also works!
When expressing how many minutes it will be till the next full hour, you put 差 (chà) in front of the time expression.
Minutes to the hour use this structure:

blocks.text: 差 + Minutes + 分 + Hour + 点
Hour + 点 + 差 + Minutes + 分

One of the definitions of the common character 几 (jǐ) is "several," "a couple" or "a few." It's an uncertain number that is at least more than one, and probably less than five, but definitely less than ten.
The simplest way to use 几 (jǐ) to mean "a few" is to use it directly with a measure word.

children.english: There are a few books on the table.
Only a few people have been to that place.
Flying from Shanghai to Tokyo only takes a few hours.
Every day I have to drink a couple cups of coffee.
The boss had a few important meetings today.

blocks.html: It is similar to how in English we can say, "a few dozen" or "a couple dozen," though in this case instead of "twelves of something" we are saying "tens of something."

blocks.text: 几 + 十 + Measure Word + Noun

children.explanation: "Dozens" is the closest we can get in natural English to the Chinese, which literally means "tens."

Our company has a few dozen employees.
He wrote a few dozen books. I like them all.

了 (le) has many uses. You probably first learned 了 (le) as a particle that tells you an action is completed, which is also known as "了1." However, this article is not about that use of 了 (le); instead, it is about indicating a change of state (了2). In other words, there is now a new situation, or there is about to be a new situation. This whole "change of state" idea can take numerous forms, and this page includes some helpful examples.
When an adjective indicates a change to the subject, 了 (le) is placed at the end of the sentence to indicate a change of state.

children.english: I'm hungry.
The kids are all tired.

children.explanation: We aren't used to thinking of her as old, but she is now.
children.english: Mom has gotten old.

children.explanation: You used to not be fat.
children.english: You've gotten fat.
Are you mad?

blocks.html: When following a verb or verb phrase, the 了 (le) indicates a change in an overall situation. For these sentences, sometimes you can translate this 了 (le) as "now."

children.explanation: It wasn't raining, but now it is.
children.english: It's raining.
The baby can speak now.
He became a manager.
You have a girlfriend now?
My boyfriend has found a new job.

blocks.html: Change of Situation in the Negative
blocks.text: Change of Situation in the Negative

blocks.html: When you take the same "change of situation" pattern and put a 不 (bù) before the verb, you're indicating that something already decided has changed. What had once been green-lit is now getting a red light. What was once "on" is now "off." The "change of situation" indicated by 了 (le) is still the same, although the change is often simply mental: it's a change of plans, or a change of intent.

children.explanation: I had previously decided to buy it.
children.english: I'm not buying it now.

children.explanation: I had previously decided to go home for dinner.
children.english: I'm not going to go home for dinner tonight.

children.explanation: I had said I was going.
children.english: I decided not to go to the movies.

children.explanation: I had previously planned to get married.
children.english: I'm not getting married.

blocks.html: This pattern is somewhat similar to expressing "not anymore" with "le".
The whole "change of state" concept might seem very general, and it is. It's vague, and it also takes some getting used to. You should expect it to take a while to get used to this use of 了 (le).

Because it's a little vague and confusing, most learners find it useful to break this "change of state" 了 (le) down into more specific usages, such as using it to mean "now", "already", or "not anymore". Although these are all "flavors" of the "change of state" 了 (le), identifying them as specific cases can make it much easier to get used to using 了 (le) in this way.

The particle 吧 (ba) can also be used to concede a point. That is, 吧 (ba) can be used to accept or agree with something that you're not particularly happy about, the way we might use "all right" or "fine then" in English.
Similar to other uses of 吧 (ba), this usage is also simply placed on the end of a sentence or statement.
To understand what someone is conceding to, it's best to present this usage as a number of super short dialogs which provide a little context.
In this first one, B has to accept that his luxury goods shopping dreams have been shattered.

children.speaker: A
children.english: That's too expensive!

children.speaker: B
children.english: All right, we can take a look at something else.

blocks.html: Now B must accept inconvenient schedule changes.

children.speaker: A
children.english: This afternoon I won't be home. Can you come by this evening?

children.speaker: B
children.english: All right.

blocks.html: B is now conceding that going out in this crazy rain doesn't make sense.

children.speaker: A
children.english: It's raining heavily. Let's go buy it tomorrow.

children.speaker: B
children.english: Fine, but tomorrow we definitely have to buy it.

blocks.html: Now B is agreeing to let more guys into his secret club.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Can I bring friends?

children.speaker: B
children.english: All right, but you can't bring girls.

blocks.html: Now B is having a friend cancel plans on him. Not a good day for B!

children.speaker: A
children.english: I'm not feeling well today. Can you go by yourself?

children.speaker: B
children.english: All right, rest well then.

You understand the word 已经 (yǐjīng) to mean "already" in Chinese, and it is followed with a 了 (le). However, sometimes, that feeling of "already" can also be expressed with 了 (le) alone if it is used in response to a preceding question or statement.
When "already" is implied using this structure, it is usually (if not always) in response to a preceding question or statement. Therefore, the following examples are in dialog format.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Where is the boss?

children.speaker: B
children.english: He has (already) left.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Are your kids still in college?

children.speaker: B
children.explanation: This expression emphasizes that they're not students anymore, and have already entered the workforce.
children.english: They (already) work.

children.speaker: A
children.english: How about using my car?

children.speaker: B
children.english: Thanks. We (already) have a car.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Are you going to tell him?

children.speaker: B
children.english: He (already) knows.

children.speaker: A
children.english: You should ask the teacher.

children.speaker: B

The particle 了 (le) has a lot of uses. One of the most common is to express the completion of an action. This is called aspect, which is not the same as tense. Tense is about when an action happens: past, present or future. With regards to 了 (le), aspect is about whether the action is complete in a certain time frame.
The simplest way to use 了 (le) is to just put it after a verb. When there's nothing else after the verb, there are no complications!

children.english: They have arrived.
I've bought it.
We all went.
I found it!

blocks.html: Putting 了 After a Verb with an Object
blocks.text: Putting 了 After a Verb with an Object

blocks.html: Here is where things start to get slightly more complicated. If the verb has an object, 了 (le) can go directly after the verb to indicate completion, but there are a few other conditions that should be met.

It's a good idea to specify the time anyway, if you're still getting used to Chinese verbs not indicating tenses by themselves. When you do this, it's generally OK to put the 了 (le) right after the verb and before the object.

children.english: This morning I ate breakfast.
Last month she went to Beijing.
At noon I met a friend.

blocks.html: When the Object's Quantity is Specified
blocks.text: When the Object's Quantity is Specified

blocks.html: This pattern works if the sentence includes more information about the object, such as how many there are.

blocks.text: Subj. + Verb + 了 + [Number + Measure Word] + Obj.

blocks.html: (Make sure you're clear on what a measure word is and how to use them.)

children.english: The teacher asked five questions.
I bought three books.
I drank two cups of coffee.

blocks.html: When 了 Comes After the Object
blocks.text: When 了 Comes After the Object

blocks.html: OK, so here's the tricky part. Even when indicating completion, the 了 (le) can sometimes go after the object. This is not a topic that can be covered in depth at the elementary level, but you should be aware that this does happen too.

children.english: I went to Taiwan last month.
I saw a UFO last night.

blocks.html: If you're upper intermediate-ish and think you can "handle the truth," also check out our more advanced, full exposé on 了 (le) after an object.
Putting 了 After Consecutive Actions

So what happens if a whole string of things happened in the past? Do you have to put a 了 (le) after each one, just like we'd put each verb in the past tense in English? Good question! The short answer is that you only need one 了 (le).

To keep things simple, we'll make the first action "coming" or "going" somewhere, which will be followed by another action. So we'll be using 来 (lái) or 去 (qù) plus a place in each sentence, and then another action. For this type of "consecutive action," 了 (le) should be placed after the final verb (or verb phrase), which marks the completion of the entire sequence.

blocks.text: Subj. + 来 / 去 + Place + Verb / [Verb Phrase] + 了

children.english: She came to my place and ate dinner yesterday.
We went to Beijing and had a meeting there last week.
I went to the mall with my friend and bought some clothes.

blocks.html: 了 (le) can appear in sentences about the future as well as the past. What's important is whether or not the action has been completed, no matter what time frame we're talking about. This also means that this 了 (le) isn't used with habitual or continuous actions.

The aspect particle 过 (guo) is used to indicate that an action has been experienced in the past.

What this expresses is that the verb has been done at least once before, without specifying a particular time. 过 (guo) is used to talk about whether something has ever happened - whether it has been experienced.

In English, if you're asking a question and really trying to figure out if someone has ever done something before, we tend to use the words "ever" and "before." In Chinese, 过 (guo) alone expresses this, without the need for additional words.

children.english: Have you ever studied Chinese?
Have you seen that person before?
We've been to this place before.
I've also eaten Japanese food before.
Have you seen this movie?

blocks.html: Because 过 (guo) is used to talk about past actions, it should be negated with 没 (méi).

blocks.text: Subj. + 没 + Verb + 过 + Obj.

blocks.html: Note that when you translate these examples into English, "have never" [done something] is often more natural, indicating that someone lacks the experience of having done something, rather than just "have not" [done something].

children.english: I've never thought about this question before.
I have never studied this word before.
Mom has never bought any expensive clothes before.
None of us has ever been on a airplane before.
Have you never seen beautiful girls before?

blocks.html: To emphasize "never" even more, you can also use the word 从来 (cónglái).
Using 过 (guo) with 了 (le)

You'll sometimes see 过 (guo) used together with 了 (le). This can be a little confusing, as it doesn't seem to be following the rules laid out above. For more on this special usage of 过 (guo), see the article on using 过 (guo) with 了 (le).

title: Expressing "not anymore" with "le"
pattern: 不 / 没(有) + Verb Phrase + 了

blocks.html: In a negative sentence, the sentence-final 了 (le) can take on the meaning of "(not) anymore" or "no longer." The word 已经 (yǐjīng), which means "already," may nor may not accompany it.
不 with Only 了
Note that without the 了 this pattern is still correct, but then the resulting sentence would no longer indicate a change (which is the whole point of the word "anymore").

children.english: I don't want to eat anymore.
You don't like me anymore?
You can't fight anymore.

blocks.html: 没有 with Only 了
Again, without the 了 this pattern is still correct, but then the resulting sentence would no longer indicate a change (which is the whole point of the word "anymore").

children.explanation: in other words, "we're out of paper"
children.english: There's no paper anymore.
My cell phone has run out of power.
He doesn't have a home anymore.

blocks.html: Adding 已经 for Emphasis

Use of the word 已经 (yǐjīng) to mean "anymore" is optional for this pattern, but either 不 (bù) or 没有 (méiyǒu) will be needed to make the verb negative. The sentence-final 了 (le) is required, though, since 已经 is used.

blocks.text: 已经 + 不 + [Verb Phrase] + 了
已经 + 没(有) + [Noun Phrase] + 了

children.english: I don't live here anymore.
He doesn't work here anymore.
They are no longer together.
We all don't have money anymore.

You may have already learned how to ask questions with 呢 (ne), but did you know that it's also used in statements? In this usage, 呢 (ne) is imparting a certain "mood" (hence the word "modal") or "attitude." It's used when trying to sound more confident and convincing to someone else.
For each of these examples, just a bit of context is needed to understand what the speaker is trying to convince someone of.

It's too far. By train, it'll take 10 hours.
I looked for you for quite a while. Where did you go?
And it's raining really heavily. Let's just not go out.
Drink some. There's a lot of cola left.
Daddy's working. He can't play with you.
He hasn't come back yet.
We still have a lot of work.
Let's eat together. We still have a lot of time.

blocks.html: The interjection 啊 (a) is often added to the end of sentences to add a tone of urgency, exclamation or excitement. However, the exact meaning often  depends on context.

When used like this, 啊 (a) is placed at the end of a statement and has a tone of exclamation, excitement or enthusiasm.  (In a lot of cases, the only English "translation" you can offer is an exclamation point.)

children.english: You're right!
This place is so pretty!
Your house is so big.
Learning Chinese is so hard!
It smells great! What is it?

blocks.html: 啊 (a) Expressing Certainty or Urgency
啊 (a) can also add a sense of certainty or urgency to a statement, sometimes with the feeling of an order.

children.english: Definitely, I think so too!
All right!
It's fine!
Be careful!
Eat some!

blocks.html: 啊 (a) Used in Questions

children.english: Are you going or what?
Are you eating or not?
Who said so?

blocks.html: The structural particle "de" has three written forms in modern Chinese, each with its own uses:

• 的 (de), most often used for modifying nouns
  • 得 (de), most often used with complements
  • 地 (de), most often used with adverbial phrases
There is also a modal particle 的 (de), not covered in this grammar point.
的 (de) Before Nouns

Before nouns, 的 (de) is used to mark possession or modification. One way to think about 的 (de) is that it works like apostrophe-"s" in English. Think of this one as the "possessive de" or "noun-modifying de."

children.english: Xiao Li's house

blocks.html: This comparison works very well for possession, as it shows how English and Chinese handle possession in a similar way. Just remember that Chinese uses this "possession" far more widely than English. Modifying, describing qualities, and assigning attributes are all handled in the same way as possession, by using 的 (de).

Another way to use 的 (de) is as an attributive. It's just a way of connecting adjectives or other words with a noun. It gives us more information about the noun, and the 的 (de) makes it clear that the extra information is connected to the noun. Here's an example:

children.english: red bicycle

blocks.html: Here 的 (de) is used to modify "bicycle" with the color "red." It attributes the color "red" to the "bicycle."
Although certainly not complete for all uses, this simple structure should help as a general guideline:

children.english: my cell phone
our teacher
beautiful clothes
a boisterous bar
my girlfriend's company

blocks.html: For you nerdier learners, 的 (de) is known to the Chinese as 白勺的 (bái-sháo de) as it's composed of the characters 白 (bái) and 勺 (sháo).
得 (de) After Verbs

This de is probably the trickiest to crack for English speakers as it has no obvious equivalent in English. 得 (de) is used to construct various kinds of complements and is usually associated with verbs. You can think of it as the "complement de."
Although certainly not complete for all uses, this simple structure should help:

children.english: do very well
speak too fast
play very happily
drive very fast
live very comfortably

blocks.html: For you nerdier learners, 得 (de) is known as 双人得 (shuāngrén de), as the character component 彳 is often referred to as 双人 (shuāngrén), or the "double person" component.

You might be wondering how the examples using 得 (de) above are different from adverbs. That's actually a really good question, but it's one that you should defer until later in your studies. Complements are a bit tricky, and you'll be learning a lot more about them at the intermediate level, so be patient!
地 (de) Before Verbs

地 (de) is used to turn adjectives into adverbs, and can be thought of as equivalent to the suffix -ly in English. You could call it the "adverb de" or "adverbial de," since it precedes verbs like adverbs do.
Although not complete for all uses, this simple structure should help:

Note that it's the "adjective + 地 (de)" structure that makes the adjective into an "adverb phrase" (called an adverbial). If it's a straight-up adverb you're using (instead of an adjective), then you don't need 地 (de) at all.
This pattern is also the least common of the three; you'll be using 的 (de) and 得 (de) a lot more in everyday communication than this one.

children.english: angrily say
happily laugh
slowly walk
sadly cry
carefully listen

blocks.html: Again, you don't have to know this, but this 地 (de) is known in Chinese as 土也地 (tǔ-yě de), as it's composed of the 土 (tǔ) component on the left with a 也 (yě) on the right.
This example is naturally going to be a little more difficult than the ones above, since we're cramming all three usages into one sentence, but you may find this useful.

children.english: You didn't do today's homework well because you didn't listen attentively in class.

You might be familiar with using 过 (guo) to indicate that an action has been experienced in the past, but then also see it used together with 了 (le). What's going on here? If you're already familiar with the basic usage of both 了 (le) and 过 (guo), then a special explanation of how they sometimes work together is now in order.
You'll notice that this pattern is often used for everyday behaviors.  It's used for actions like "eating" and "brushing one's teeth" and "taking a shower."

children.english: She has eaten (already).
I've brushed my teeth (already).
I've showered (already).
We've seen it (already).
They've met (already).

blocks.html: The Pattern with an Object
For the examples above, you could have inserted an object to modify the basic pattern, getting this:
The object has been inserted in the sentences below:

children.english: Have you eaten (already)?
I have brushed my teeth (already).
He has showered (already).
I called him (already).
Has the client read the contract (already)?

blocks.html: What 过 (guo) Does

You would be right to point out that 过 (guo) is mainly used to call attention to the fact that someone has had an experience. This is the basic pattern pointed out in the article on the basic usage of the aspectual particle 过 (guo). In the examples above, though, it's not any "once-in-a-lifetime" experiences being expressed, it's more just the information that these actions are done. Here, 过 (guo) and 了 (le) work together to emphasize that an action is already done. This is why the translations on the side add the word "already" in parentheses at the end; this is the feeling the sentences give you. In fact, to emphasize the idea of already done even further, you could add the word for "already," 已经 (yǐjīng), before the verbs in the examples below, and it also works just fine:

children.english: She has already eaten (a meal).
I have already brushed my teeth.
He has already had a shower.

blocks.html: When to Use 过 (guo) with 了 (le)
blocks.text: When to Use 过 (guo) with 了 (le)

blocks.html: So when would you use the sentences above? You'd be emphasizing that the action has already occurred (so it doesn't need to be done again), so it would probably be something like this:

children.speaker: A
children.english: Does she want to eat?

children.speaker: B
children.english: She has already eaten.

children.speaker: A
children.english: Don't forget to brush your teeth.

children.speaker: B
children.english: I have already brushed my teeth.

blocks.html: For the taking a shower example:

children.speaker: A
children.english: He should take a shower.

children.speaker: B
children.english: He has already showered.

One of the most common words when comparing things in Chinese is to use 比 (bǐ). 比 (bǐ) has similarities to the English word "than," but it requires a word order that's not so intuitive, so you'll want to practice it quite a bit.

You could think of 比 (bǐ) as meaning "than," except that it sits between the two things being compared. The word order will take a little getting used to, but aside from that, the pattern is quite easy.
To say that one thing is more adjective than another, the structure is:
The noun that's placed first is the one that comes out on top in the comparison. So in the sentence:

children.english: Xiao Li is taller than Xiao Zhang.

blocks.html: 小李 (Xiǎo Lǐ) is taller. The same situation could be described as

children.english: Xiao Zhang is shorter than Xiao Li.
He is smarter than the teacher.
Is Shanghai bigger than New York?
She is prettier than her mother.
The coffee at Starbucks is more expensive than the coffee here.
The subway is more convenient than the bus.

blocks.html: Try not to make these mistakes:
很 (hěn) can't used in the comparison.

children.english: He's taller than me.

blocks.html: The adjective used in the comparison should be positive, not negative.

children.english: He's taller than me.

blocks.html: 比 (bǐ) is not used with 一样 (yīyàng). 比 (bǐ) is used when two things are not the same.

children.english: I'm as tall as him.

blocks.html: Pattern Using 比 (bǐ) and 更 (gèng)
blocks.text: Pattern Using 比 (bǐ) and 更 (gèng)

blocks.html: This is a slight upgrade of the basic 比 (bǐ) comparison pattern, adding in 更 (gèng) before the adjective. 更 (gèng) means "even more," so the idea is that while one thing is already quite [adjective], this other thing is even more [adjective]. Pretty simple!

blocks.text: Noun 1 + 比 + Noun 2 + 更 + Adj.

blocks.html: The only new thing here is the addition of 更 (gèng) before the adjective.

children.english: Xiao Li is even taller than Xiao Zhang.

blocks.html: The implication is that while Xiao Zhang is tall, 小李 (Xiǎo Lǐ) is even taller.

children.english: My big brother is even taller than me.
Your boyfriend is even more handsome than mine.
The winter here is even colder than it is in New York.
Chinese grammar is even more fun than Chinese characters.
Your problem is even more troublesome than mine.

The "time" here does not necessarily have to be a standard time word; it can be any event or action.

children.english: from 2004 to 2008

From Tuesday until Friday the boss will go on a business trip.
She's lived alone since she was 18 until now.
You can't eat nothing from morning to night.

children.english: from West Nanjing Road to East Nanjing Road

From here to our company, you'll see many beautiful girls.

In Chinese, there is another way to make comparisons. You can use 没有 (méiyǒu) to express that something is "not as" adjective as something else. (Yes, that's the same 没有 (méiyǒu) that means "not have," used here in a different way.)

As well as with 比 (bǐ), you can also use 没有 (méiyǒu) to make basic comparisons. You could think of 没有 (méiyǒu) as the opposite of 比 (bǐ) - it works in the same way, but rather than expressing "more... than..." it expresses "not as... as...":
In this structure, the noun that's placed first is less "adjective" than the second noun, making 没有 (méiyǒu) the opposite of 比 (bǐ) for comparison purposes. So in the sentence:

children.english: Xiao Zhang is not as tall as Xiao Li.

blocks.html: 小李 (Xiǎo Lǐ) is taller. The same situation could be described as:

children.english: Xiao Li is not as short as Xiao Zhang.
This place is not as fun as Shanghai.
Trains are not as fast as airplanes.
He's not as smart as his younger brother.
Clinton is not as handsome as Obama.
Jack Ma is not as rich as Bill Gates.
Your company is not as big as ours.
Pinyin is not as difficult as Chinese characters.
Taking the bus is not as convenient as taking the metro.
The Xiaomi phone is not as expensive as the iPhone.
The food dad cooks is not as tasty as the food mom cooks.

来 (lái) and 去 (qù) are both words that help to express direction from the perspective of the speaker. 来 (lái) means "come" (towards the speaker), while 去 (qù) means "go" (away from the speaker). For example, if you are in China, a local person might ask you: "When did you come to China?" using 来 (lái). Another example is if you want to go from China to Japan, your friends might ask you:  “When are you going to Japan?" using 去 (qù).
Seems really easy, right? Well, learn them well now, because you'll get a lot of mileage out of these words in future grammar patterns.

For the examples below, keep in mind that if the speaker uses 去 (qù), then she is not at the place mentioned now. If the speaker uses 来 (lái), she must already be at the place mentioned. Just stay consistent with this, and you're good.

children.english: Mom will go to the supermarket.
Is the boss coming into the office today?
Come to Nanjing Road now.
Do you not want to come to work for our company?
Last year she went to work in the USA for a few months.
Would you like to go to Starbucks or Costa?
I like to go to my friends' places on the weekends.
Dad will go to Beijing on a business trip tomorrow.
I don't have to go to work today. You can come to my home to eat dinner.

blocks.html: 来 (lái) and  去 (qù) can both be paired with other simple verbs to demonstrate the direction an action has taken. For example, 进来 (jìnlai, "come in"),  进去 (jìnqu, "go in"),  出来 (chūlai, "come out"),  出去 (chūqu, "go out"), 回来 (huílai, "come back"), 回去 (huíqu, "go back"), etc.
When you start tacking these two-character verbs onto the ends of other verbs, they are called direction complements, and are covered in detail in a more advanced article.
To be more polite in English, we add the word "please" onto our requests. In Chinese, the word 请 (qǐng) serves the same purpose.
In its most simple form, a polite request can consist of only two words.

children.english: Please come in.
Please sit down.
Please speak.

blocks.html: Obviously, those requests may be significantly longer.

children.english: Please have some tea.
Please do not be late.
Please have a taste.
Please speak more slowly.
Please listen to the teacher.
Please leave.

blocks.html: The phrase 请问 (qǐngwèn) is a set expression meaning not "please ask," but rather, "may I ask." It frequently comes before asking for directions or other polite requests for information.

children.english: Excuse me, where is the restroom?

blocks.html: You may have noticed that the Chinese themselves do not use 请 (qǐng) nearly as much as we use the word "please" in English. It's not because Chinese people are rude; it's because the word 请 (qǐng) feels rather formal in Chinese, and most people don't feel the need to use it with family members, friends, or even co-workers.
Here are some other ways to start make a request to still be polite, but less in a less formal way:

children.english: Could you...?
Can you...?
Can I trouble you to... (?)

blocks.html: More Advanced Uses of 请 (qǐng)

Aside from this "please" usage, the word 请 (qǐng) has some additional uses not covered here. It can mean "to invite," or "to treat (someone to a meal)," and can even be used as a causative verb. None of those uses are covered here.

title: Auxiliary verb "yao" and its multiple meanings

blocks.html: You probably already know the basic meaning of 要 (yào) as "to want." It is actually a quite versatile word, though, and can also take on the meanings of "to need" as well as "will (do something)." In every case, context is crucial for figuring out which meaning someone is trying to express.
This structure could be used when ordering food at a restaurant or a shop. Here, it's being used for saying that you want something.

children.english: What do you want?
I want a cup of water.
Do you all want coke with ice?
Do you want tea or coffee?
We want three bowls of rice.

blocks.html: In Chinese, 要 (yào) can mean "want to" (similar to 想 (xiǎng)), but its tone is quite firm. So it's used for saying that you want to do something.

children.english: What kind of wine do you want to drink?
Dad wants to buy a new cell phone.
I want to go with you.
She wants to go to a big city to find a job.
Do you want to go see a movie together this weekend?

blocks.html: If you crank the urgency of "to want" up a few notches, you get "to need."  The two meanings overlap, creating a fuzzy, "needy" gray area.

children.english: You need to go to bed earlier.

children.explanation: logically, most people don't really WANT to work
children.english: We need to work tomorrow.
Today the boss needs to see a new client.
The teacher is too tired. She needs to rest well.
It's going to rain tomorrow; you need to bring an umbrella.

blocks.html: This use of 要 (yào) is like "going to" (similar to 会 (huì)).
Again, no change to the structure here, but it often includes a mention of a time when something is going to happen.
If you want to know more about the related pattern "要⋯⋯了" (yào... le), please see the "kuai... le" pattern.

children.english: We are going to have a meeting on Friday.
I am going to go eat at 12 o'clock.
Is the boss going on a business trip next week?
They are going to get married next year.
Are you going to return home this year to celebrate the Chinese New Year?

blocks.html: You may have noticed that the meanings can easily overlap. To figure out what is intended, you need to use context. How urgent is the situation? Is it likely to be something the speaker really wants to do? Is it something that's totally going to happen, regardless of anyone's preference? Most often, a little background knowledge and some common sense are all you need to figure it out.

应该 (yīnggāi) translates to the English word "should," and is an essential word to know for your conversaitonal Chinese. You should definitely get comfortable using 应该 (yīnggāi) right away!
The auxiliary verb 应该 (yīnggāi) is the most common way to express "should" in Chinese. The structure is:

children.english: In China, you should drink baijiu.
How much money should I give you?
You should drink hot water when you have a cold.
You should come to the office tomorrow at 8:30.
He's too tired. He should go home and rest.

blocks.html: Negate 应该 (yīnggāi) with 不 (bù)
Add the negative adverb 不 (bù) before 应该 (yīnggāi) to negate it.

blocks.text: Subj. + 不 + 应该 + Verb + Obj.

children.english: You should not tell him.
He should not hit people.
We shouldn't be late.
You shouldn't laugh at her.
You should not take other people's stuff.

Your daughter will listen to you.
After getting off work, I will give you a call.

Nothing new here. You remember everyone's favorite Negative Nelly 不 (bù), right?

blocks.html: If you want to express something that you "would like to do," 想 (xiǎng) will be a very helpful auxiliary verb to know. Although similar to 要 (yào), 想 (xiǎng) will give you another more tactful option when you want to articulate a desire.

children.english: Would you like to go?
I would like to eat noodles.
Would you like to drink some water?
We would like to watch TV.
He would like to buy a big apartment.

Linking actions together in a sentence is very straightforward and to the point. Because of this, there is no new word or phrase needed!
In Chinese, it's very easy to describe two actions in a row. Simply place one verb phrase after another, in this structure:

No connecting word is needed. A common mistake in the early stages of learning Chinese is to try and link verbs with 和 (hé). This is incorrect; 和 (hé) is for linking nouns. Just use one verb phrase after another and the sequence of events is clear.

children.english: I want to go home and eat.
Are you going to the supermarket to buy things?
He doesn't want to go to the library and read.
Did you call and tell him?
We are going to take an airplane to go to the USA.
Can you use the Internet to buy airplane tickets?
Next week the boss will go to Beijing to have a meeting.
Chinese people all go back home for Chinese New Year.
I like to buy food to cook for myself on the weekend.
In the morning, I first brush my teeth and wash my face, and then I eat breakfast.

blocks.html: 难 (nán) is an adjective that means "difficult." When something is "hard to do" (as in difficult), the word 难 (nán) can be used before the verb.
Just as 好 (hǎo) can be used to indicate that it's easy to do something, 难 (nán) can be attached to verbs (with a few special exceptions), to indicate that something is hard to do.

children.english: This sentence is hard to understand.
Mandarin is hard to learn.
Chinese food is hard to make.
This thing is really difficult to purchase now.
This character is very difficult to write.

blocks.html: 难 (nán) can also be attached to "sense verbs" (e.g. look, taste, smell, etc.) to indicate that something offers a "bad sensory experience."

children.english: The dishes you cook taste bad.
The coffee here tastes bad.
This song is terrible (hard to listen to).
This kind of flower smells bad.
Is this article of clothing ugly?

blocks.html: Warning! If you're trying to say that a particular dish is "difficult to eat," don't use 难吃 (nánchī)! The word 难吃 (nánchī) only means "bad-tasting" and not "difficult to eat."

Whether you need to express how long you lived somewhere, how long you studied astrophysics, or how long you worked as a mime, you'll need to use 了 (le) to express that time duration.
Saying how long you did something for in Chinese can seem tricky, as there is no preposition as in English. Instead it's all about word order:
So 了 (le) is placed after the verb (to indicate that the action is completed), followed by the duration. This is how you talk about the duration of completed actions.

children.english: He studied Chinese for a year.
I read books all evening.
He worked as a manager for eight years.

blocks.html: Also note that 的 can be used in this pattern, which must be placed between the duration and the object.

blocks.text: Subj. + Verb + 了 + Duration + 的 + Obj.

children.english: We took a fifteen hour flight.
Grandma watched TV all day.
Mom washed clothes all morning.

blocks.html: Note that the previous pattern can be used to express the duration of completed actions which are no longer in progress, although strictly speaking, it's not entirely clear if the actions are still ongoing or not. To indicate that the actions are definitely concluded (not ongoing), a time word may be inserted into the sentence to indicate that you're talking about an event in the past:

blocks.text: Subj. + [Time Word] + Verb + 了 + Duration + Obj.

children.english: The kids did their homework all day Saturday.
I was on the phone for half an hour.
Yesterday, I played games all evening.
He drove all day yesterday.
The boss had meetings all afternoon today.

blocks.html: To indicate that the action is definitely still in progress, use a slightly different pattern.
