title: Expressing "never" with "conglai"
pattern: 从来 + 不 / 没(有) + Verb

blocks.html: Although it can also work in the positive, 从来 (cónglái) is usually used when you want to express that you never do something (as a habit, or as a rule), or that you have never done something (it's not a part of your life experience). In either usage, 从来 (cónglái) may be shortened to just 从 (cóng) in casual speech.
"To Never Do" with 从来 (cónglái) + 不 (bù)
blocks.text: "To Never Do" with 从来 (cónglái) + 不 (bù)

blocks.html: When you follow 从来 (cónglái) with 不 (bù), you are expressing that you never do something (as a habit, or as a rule). It's often used as a way to refuse something, as in "I never drink."
Keep in mind that 从来 (cónglái) may be shortened to just 从 (cóng) in casual speech.

children.english: She never drinks.
My girlfriend never calls me.
This person is very strange. He never laughs.
Your parents never hit you?
He never cares about other people.

blocks.html: "To Have Never Done" with 从来 (cónglái) + 没有 (méiyǒu)
blocks.text: "To Have Never Done" with 从来 (cónglái) + 没有 (méiyǒu)

blocks.html: Use 从来 (cónglái) with 没 (méi) or 没有 (méiyǒu) (and 过 (guo) after the verb) to indicate that you have never done something (it's not a part of your life experience). You're talking about the past now, because you're talking about what you haven't done before, so 没有 (méiyǒu) is appropriate. 过 (guo) also makes sense, because you're making a statement about your life experience.

blocks.text: Subj. + 从来 + 没(有) + Verb + 过

blocks.html: Again, 从来 (cónglái) may be shortened to just 从 (cóng) in casual speech. Note that you can have an object or other information after the verb, but the 过 (guo) needs to come immediately after the verb.

children.english: Have you never thought about this question?
She has never met her mother.

The 了 (le) particle is used in many different ways. In this article, we will explore how to use the double 了 (le) to express the duration of an activity that is ongoing.
Expressing how long you did something in the past is one thing, but what if the action is still ongoing?
A clarifying example (in English) is appropriate:

• I lived in Shanghai for 5 years. (concluded, not ongoing)
  • I have lived in Shanghai for 5 years. (mostly likely ongoing)
  • I have been living in Shanghai for 5 years. (definitely ongoing)
This article is about expressing the third situation above, the one which is definitely ongoing.

blocks.text: Subj. + Verb + 了 + Duration + 了

blocks.html: The first 了 (le) is placed after the verb (to indicate that the action is completed), followed by the duration, followed by an additional 了 (le) which tells us that the action has not concluded and is ongoing.  You can think of the second 了 (le) as communicating the meaning of "up until now."

children.english: You have been sleeping for the whole day.
He has been living in Beijing for two years.
They've been holding this meeting for the past two hours.
I have been waiting here for half an hour.
They have been staying at the bar for the whole evening.

The boss has been playing video games all morning.

Mom has been watching TV all evening.

One easy way to express inability is to place the phrase 没办法 (méi bànfǎ) before the verb.

If you need to include the place where an action takes place, you can use 在 (zài). Just pay close attention to word order, as this is one case in which Chinese word order is quite different from English.
To indicate the location that a verb takes place in, 在 (zài), followed by a location, comes before the verb.
Notice that the location is placed before the verb in Chinese, whereas in English it appears afterwards.

children.english: I went to college in Shanghai.
Have you always been working in this company?
On the weekend, I want to sleep at home.

children.explanation: In addition to "在" you need a "上" to indicate the location "on the bed."
children.english: Don't eat food on the bed.
Where do you want to have the birthday party?

children.explanation: In addition to "在" you need a "里" to indicate the location "in the bathroom."
children.english: He likes to smoke in the bathroom.

children.explanation: In addition to "在" you need a "上" to indicate the location "in the subway."
children.english: Many people eat breakfast on the subway.
Now we're singing songs at karaoke.
The boss is seeing the client in the meeting room.
Did you eat dinner outside?

blocks.html: Remember: in English we usually put the location at the end of a sentence. In Chinese, we put the location after the subject but before the verb.

Rather than just using 在 (zài) to mean "at" a location, you might want to use it to mean "in," "on," or "under" a specific location. To do this, you'll need to add an extra word after the location. Learn about expressing location with "zai... shang / xia / li".

blocks.html: One of the fun things about Chinese is that when speaking, you can repeat a verb to express "a little bit" or "briefly." This is called reduplication. It creates a casual tone, and a sense that whatever the action is, it's not going to take long.
In Chinese, verbs can be reduplicated to indicate that they happen briefly or "a little bit."
Chinese grammar books frequently refer to the reduplication of a single-character word as a "AA" pattern. Note that for this pattern, the second verb's tone changes to the neutral tone.

children.english: Take a little look.
I'll give it a try.
Talk a little bit about your ideas.
Go out and have fun!
I want to go out and walk for a bit.

blocks.html: Another way to reduplicate verbs is to insert 一 (yī), in the following structure:

children.english: Don't be mad, gimme a smile!
Go and ask them where the bathroom is.
Can I use your computer for a little bit?
Do you have a second? Let's chat for a bit.
Do you want to taste the food that I cooked?

blocks.html: Using this kind of structure lightens the mood and seriousness of the question. It also adds variety to sentence structure. Because these phrases are used colloquially, there is no set rule to which verbs this can be applied to. There are some verbs that are often reduplicated and some verbs that sound weird when reduplicated. With practice and exposure, you will learn which ones are often used.

In the examples above, all verbs are only one syllable. Those verbs get reduplicated a lot, so those examples are quite useful. Occasionally, though, two-syllable verbs get reduplicated as well. When this happens, it's important to use the "ABAB" pattern for verbs (meaning the entire word is repeated), and not the "AABB" pattern you use for adjectives (where each character is repeated individually).

discuss it
talk it over
inquire about it

blocks.html: When used to indicate locations of actions, 在 (zài) is usually placed after the subject and before the verb. There are certain cases, however, when 在 (zài) goes after the verb.

This pattern is used regularly with special types of verbs, including: 住 (zhù), 放 (fàng), 坐 (zuò), and 站 (zhàn). These are verbs that imply movement or location. Just remember that for verbs implying movement or location like the ones above, the default sentence order changes and you get this structure:

Don't stand in the middle of the road.
Don't sit on the ground.
I placed that book on the table.
Don't walk on the grass.
I don't want to stay at home on weekends.

blocks.html: Remember that this is an exception to the normal rule. A common mistake is to over apply this and produce incorrect sentences. Note the incorrect and correct versions below.

children.english: I work in Shanghai.
I study in the library.

blocks.html: Using 很 (hěn) to intensify verbs that express thoughts or feeling is really easy.

Certain "psychological verbs" related to feelings or emotional sates can be modified with 很 (hěn) to increase their intensity. This is similar to using "really" or "very much" in English. Remember that this only applies to psychological verbs, such as:

• 想 (xiǎng) to think; to want; to miss
  • 喜欢 (xǐhuan) to like
  • 小心 (xiǎoxīn) to be careful
  • 怕 (pà) to fear; to be afraid of
  • 了解 (liǎojiě) to know a lot about
  • 讨厌 (tǎoyàn) to hate
  • 担心 (dānxīn) to worry about
  • 希望 (xīwàng) to hope

He really likes you.
You should be very careful.
I fear staying home alone at night.
You should know a lot about your child.
Foreigners really hate public toilets in China.
You haven't gone home in two days. Mom is really worried about you.
Both of my parents really hope that I can go to a good college.

A simple and direct way to indicate that you or someone is going to a specific place or has arrived at a specific place is to use the verb 到 (dào).
到 (dào) for Arriving in a Place
blocks.text: 到 (dào) for Arriving in a Place

blocks.html: The verb 到 (dào) is used to talk about arriving in places.
For these examples, it's straightforward to think of 到 (dào) as simply meaning "to arrive."

children.english: They have already arrived at the bar.
I just got home.
Have you arrived at the airport?
I've already arrived at the train station.
First we'll arrive in Beijing, then in Hong Kong.

blocks.html: In some examples translating 到 (dào) as "to arrive" doesn't work as well and you might need to expand your understanding of exactly what 到 (dào) means. That's what we'll examine below.
到 (dào) for Coming or Going to a Place
blocks.text: 到 (dào) for Coming or Going to a Place

blocks.html: One commonly used structure takes the above one and adds a 来 (lái) or 去 (qù) to the end of the sentence.

children.english: I'll be home this afternoon. You can come to my house.
The boss is going to the office right now.

blocks.html: Going to a Place and Performing an Action
blocks.text: Going to a Place and Performing an Action

blocks.html: If you are going to a place to do something else, you can first use 到 (dào) to indicate where you're going, then add another verb after that. This has the meaning of "going to the place to do something," and it's one case where the "arrive" translation doesn't really work anymore.

children.english: Tomorrow I'll go to Nanjing Road to buy clothes.
Where will you all go to eat food this evening?
I often go to Karaoke to sing songs with friends.
This Spring Festival I am going to my girlfriend's house to meet her parents.
Next month I need to go to the USA on a business trip.

blocks.html: You might be wondering: can I just use 去 (qù) instead of 到 (dào)? For sentences like this, yes, you can. But native speakers will frequently use 到 (dào) in this way, so it's still good to be familiar with this pattern. If you want to sound more native, you should use it too!
到 (dào), 去 (qù), and 走 (zǒu)

Sometimes it can be hard to figure out exactly which word to use in Chinese to mean "go." 到 (dào) is used when you talk about arriving at a place, emphasizing the destination. 去 (qù) is used when you are going to a place. The exact meaning is "to go," and it emphasizes getting to somewhere. 走 (zǒu) is used when talking about "leaving." The emphasis is on getting away from a particular place.

Of course 好 (hǎo) means "good." But it can also be used to express that something is "easy to do" or "good to do." And it is quite... easy to do! All you need to do is place a 好 (hǎo) before a verb.
Just as 难 (nán) can be used to indicate that it's hard to do something, 好 (hǎo) can also come before verbs to indicate that something is easy to do.
If you want to make a sentence out of it:

children.english: The meaning of this word is easy to understand.
This Chinese character is easy to write.
Sandwiches are easy to make.
iPhones are easy to buy now.
This pen is easy to use.

blocks.html: 好 (hǎo) can also be attached to "sense verbs" (e.g. "look," "taste," "smell," etc.) to indicate that something is good to do (rather than "easy to do").
There's a limited number of these, but some of them are super common, so just memorize them as exceptions:

children.english: good to taste, good to eat, delicious
good to taste, good to drink
good to look at, good-looking, attractive
good to listen to, pleasant to listen to, good-sounding
good to smell, smells good, good-smelling

blocks.html: The word for "fun" in Chinese is also of this form, even though it's not a sense verb:

children.english: fun
This song is great.
This kind of tea smells good.
Your new bag looks good.
The food mom makes is delicious.
I think Shanghai is a lot of fun.

Note: The pinyin for 一下 is written "yīxià" but pronounced "yíxià" due to a tone change rule.
To express that a verb is carried out briefly or "a little bit," you can add 一下 (yīxià) after it. Sometimes 一下 (yīxià) can soften the tone.

Often, adding 一下 (yīxià) just makes the Chinese feel more natural.  This is not something you can get a feel for quickly.  You'll want to observe how native speakers use 一下 (yīxià)  over a long period of time to really get used to how it is used.

title: Potential complement "-bu dong" for not understanding

blocks.html: Chinese learners often have to express that they don't understand something, especially in the beginning when they start learning. One of the ways to express that is to use the 不懂 (bù dǒng) verb complement.
Yes, 不懂 (bù dǒng) by itself simply means "not understand," and you can use it this way. But you'll find that more often, it follows a verb. When used this way, it is a complement.
The potential complement 不懂 (bù dǒng) is used to talk about things that can't be understood. Note that this is about potential: the subject doesn't have the ability to understand.
The 不懂 (bù dǒng) may also be swapped out with 不明白 (bù míngbai).

children.english: I don't understand the book.
Kids don't understand the characters that you wrote.
Do you not understand my emails?
The boss speaks very good Chinese, but he doesn't understand Chinese newspapers.
I don't understand Shanghai dialect.
Do you not understand what I say?
I don't understand your English.
None of us understand what you mean.
Many people don't understand this book.
This sentence is very difficult. None of the students understand.

Two of the most common result complements in Chinese are 到 (dào) and 见 (jiàn). On this page we're only going to be talking about verbs related to the senses ("see," "hear," etc.), and for this usage, the two are interchangeable.
Verbs with 到 (dào) and 见 (jiàn)
blocks.text: Verbs with 到 (dào) and 见 (jiàn)

blocks.html: Result complements are a huge topic in Chinese grammar, but you can approach them in stages. The structure you come across the most is a verb with 到 (dào):

What 到 (dào) does is indicate that the outcome of the verb is achieved - what its result is. Without a result complement, the sentence would describe only the action itself. To illustrate, 看 (kàn) "to look" is the action of turning your head in a particular direction and focusing your eyes, whereas 看到 (kàndào), "to see," is the result of your brain taking in the visual input. It may sound a little hokey, but it really is possible to "look but not see," and Chinese makes a clear distinction between the action and the result.
The complement 见 (jiàn) is very similar to 到 (dào), and it is used in the same way:

However, there is a difference. 见 (jiàn) is generally only used after verbs involving one of the senses, like 听 (tīng) and 看 (kàn), whereas 到 (dào) can be attached to a large variety of verbs, which we will discuss at a higher level later.

children.english: Did you see that handsome guy?

children.explanation: We didn't say what "I" saw; you have to infer it from the context.

children.english: I saw it.
Did you hear it?

blocks.text: Subj. + 没 + Verb + 到 / 见 + Obj.

blocks.html: This structure can be negated using 没 (méi) on 没有 (méiyǒu). This is because if there is a result, then it already happened. And you need to use 没 (méi) to negate past events, not 不 (bù).

children.english: You didn't see that handsome guy?

children.explanation: We didn't say what "I" didn't see; you have to infer it from the context.
children.english: I didn't see it.
You didn't hear it?

On its own, 完 (wán) means "to finish" or "to complete." Using it in this grammar structure, it expresses the idea of doing some action to completion.
As well as with 到 (dào) and 见 (jiàn), you can also form result complements with 完 (wán). This indicates that an action is finished or completed.

children.english: We can finish doing it tomorrow.
Can you finish eating all?
I need to finish writing it today.
I didn't finish reading it.

blocks.html: Usage of 完了 (wán le)
Frequently, you'll also see a 了 (le) at the end, indicating completion.

children.english: I am finished talking.
Are you done eating?
I have finished watching it.
It's sold out.
We finished cleaning.

blocks.html: Where to put the object
If there is an object followed by the verb, 完 must be placed between the verb and the object. To indicate completion, 了 usually goes after the object.

blocks.text: Subj. + Verb + 完 + Obj. + 了

children.english: I finished doing my homework.
The boss finished having the meeting.
I finished reading this book.
We finished studying this lesson.

blocks.html: In English we say "I finished the movie," or "I finished supper," but in Chinese you should explicitly use the verb implied in English along with 完了 (wán le) to emphasize that you completed the action: "watch the movie (till the end)" or "eat (all my) supper."

children.explanation: To tell us that you watched it till the end.
children.english: I finished watching the movie.

After class, the students asked some questions.
Give me some time, OK?
He brought me some books.
Can you lend me some money?
Do you want to put some sugar in your coffee?

To refer to just certain members of group, you can use 有的 (yǒude). This usage is normally translated as "some" in English. It is often used multiple times in one sentence to refer to different groups.

All you need to do is put 有的 (yǒude) before the nouns there are "some of" in the sentence. If there is already some context, you can omit the subject, and the 有的 (yǒude) can just mean "some" instead of "some of something."

blocks.text: 有的 + (Subj.) + Predicate， 有的 + (Subj.) + Predicate

blocks.html: Also, you aren't limited to just two 有的 (yǒude) in the sentence. You can have multiple groups doing different things, and just precede them with a 有的 (yǒude) each time.

children.english: Some foreigners are rich, but some aren't.
Our company has some computers. Some are new, and some are old.
He has written a lot of books. Some sell well, but some don't.
Some Chinese foods are tasty, while some aren't.
In this shop, some of the clothes are expensive and some are cheap.
He has a lot of houses, some of them are within the country and some are abroad.
After six o'clock some people are off work, while some are still working.
Some of my college teachers are young, some are old.
In the bar, some people are drinking, some are dancing, and some are chatting.
I know a lot of people because of my work. Some are college teachers and some are CEOs.

title: Counting money
pattern: Number + 块 / 元 (+ Number + 毛 / 角) (+ 钱)

blocks.html: Cash is king, even though China is now crazy for mobile payments. Either way, though, mastering how to say quantities of money is vital!
Asking "How Much Money" with 多少钱 (duōshao qián)
blocks.text: Asking "How Much Money" with 多少钱 (duōshao qián)

blocks.html: Before you learn how to count money in Chinese, make sure you know how to ask "how much money" when you go shopping in China.

children.english: How much?
How much was your cell phone?
How much is our lunch?
How much for this cup of coffee?
How much is this clothing?

blocks.html: Chinese has a specific structure for talking about quantities for money:

children.english: two kuai five mao (2.5)
three kuai eight mao (3.8)
ten kuai two mao (10.2)
Twenty-three kuai eight mao (23.8)
fifty kuai five mao (50.5)

blocks.html: Note that "2.5 RMB" reads as 两块五 (liǎng kuài wǔ).

children.english: two kuai five mao (2.5)

blocks.html: If the smaller units are only in tens, you can just say the number of tens. So "3.8 RMB" is 三块八 (sān kuài bā). This way of giving the price is normally only used for amounts under 100 RMB.
When the smallest unit is 2, it reads as 二 (èr) instead of 两 (liǎng).

children.english: two kuai two mao (2.2)
five kuai two mao (5.2)

blocks.html: The first number is the amount of whole RMB (or dollars etc.), and the second is the amount smaller units (e.g. cents). So "3.86 RMB" is

children.english: three kuai eight mao six fen (3.86)

blocks.html: And if there's no smaller unit, e.g. "3 RMB," you can just say:

children.english: Three kuai

blocks.html: 块 (kuài) is the more common, informal way to talk about money. More formally you can use 元 (yuán) in exactly the same way. This is similar to the difference between "dollars" and "bucks" in American English, or "pounds" and "quid" in British English. 块 (kuài) is appropriate in more situations than "bucks" or "quid," though.

In this article we will look at the structure for saying "every" in Chinese, which is slightly more involved than just throwing in the word 每 (měi).
The pronoun 每 (měi) covers the meanings of "each" and "every." It should normally be used with a measure word and used with 都 (dōu) in a complete sentence.

blocks.text: 每 + Measure Word + Noun + 都

blocks.html: Note that there are some words that don't use measure words because they themselves are already measure words. For example: 天 (tiān), 年 (nián), 周 (zhōu), 次 (cì) etc.

children.english: Every dish is delicious.
Do you know every person?
The boss goes on business trips every month.
Every morning he skips breakfast.
He comes to China every year.
I give mom a phone call every week.
Each of the students in this class are very smart.
Every day the teacher gives us a lot of homework.
Every week we need to have a meeting.
Every weekend they go to the park.

The Chinese word 半 (bàn) means "half." That's simple enough, but what can get slightly tricky is the rules for how it combines with measure words.
You'll need to use a measure word (Measure Word) in this structure.
The measure words are also indicated below.

children.english: half an hour
half a month
half a bowl of rice
half a bottle of liquor
half a serving of chow mein

blocks.html: When it's more than just a half, then 半 (bàn) comes after the measure word instead of before. It's the difference between "half an hour" and "an hour and a half."

children.english: half an hour
an hour and a half

blocks.html: The order is actually basically the same as what we do in English (we just don't have so many pesky measure words to keep track of in English!).

children.english: three and a half hours
two and a half months
one and a half jin of fruit
one and a half bottles of wine
four and a half pieces of chocolate

blocks.html: There are some words that act as their own measure words, notably the time words 天 (tiān), meaning "day," and 年 (nián), meaning "year."

children.english: half a day
half a year

blocks.html: Note that you do not need to use 个 (gè) here; in fact, it's wrong to do so:

children.english: half a day
half a year

blocks.html: 天 (tiān) and 年 (nián) aren't the only words that take this alternate pattern, but they're the two key ones you need to learn first.

children.english: two and a half days
a year and a half
three and a half days
four and a half years

blocks.html: • Structure of times

Chinese uses measure words, a type of word called classifiers in linguistics which are common in East Asian languages. Measure words have a number of important uses, but one of the first ways you'll need to use them is for counting. Chinese learners should master them, starting with the measure word 个 (gè).
Whenever you talk about the quantity of something in Chinese, you need a measure word.

English does actually have measure words, it's just that most nouns usually don't need them. In English, most nouns are count nouns - they specify one instance of something. "An apple," for example. Some nouns are mass nouns and refer to something without specifying how much of it there is. Examples are "furniture," "paper," "water," etc. You can't say "a furniture"; you need a measure word: "a piece of furniture," "two sheets of paper," "three glasses of water," and so on.

In Chinese, all nouns are mass nouns so they all need measure words. Just as in English, different nouns are associated with different measure words (e.g. it wouldn't make sense to talk about "a glass of furniture" unless something went horribly wrong in the factory).

children.english: a person
two cats
three fish
four glasses of milk
five bottles of water
six pieces of chocolate
seven boxes of tea leaves
eight computers
nine roses
ten beautiful women

blocks.html: Also remember that there isn't a one-to-one relationship between nouns and measure words. One measure word can be used with several different nouns:

children.english: a dog
a river
a road
a dragon
a fish
a text (message)

blocks.html: And one noun can take different measure words in different situations:

children.english: a piece of chocolate
a box of chocolate
a small piece of chocolate

title: Measure words with "this" and "that"
pattern: 这 / 那 + Measure Word (+ Noun)

blocks.html: In English, when you refer to "this table" or "that girl" you only need two words: "this" or "that" plus the noun you're referring to. In Chinese, though, you also need a measure word in the middle between the two. In the very beginning you can get away with using 个 (gè) for everything, but pretty soon you're going to have to start using other measure words in these simple phrases.
If you use 这 (zhè) or 那 (nà) before a noun, you also need to include a measure word before the noun.

blocks.text: 这 / 那 + Measure Word + Noun

blocks.html: Note: In this usage, the tone of 个 (gè) tends to soften, so it's represented below as a neutral tone.

children.english: that person
this book
that matter (in the sense of business, affair, or thing)
this bottle of beer
that room
that new computer
that cat
that river
this piece of clothing

blocks.html: Although we didn't get into it here, the same pattern holds true when you use 哪 (nǎ) to ask "which?"

We use ordinal numbers to express things like "number one" or "second," so mastering them in Chinese is important. Fortunately, they are also very easy to learn by just adding the prefix 第 (dì).

In English, there are four different suffixes for ordinal numbers: -st, -nd, -rd and -th. Chinese makes things a lot simpler by using one prefix for all ordinal numbers: 第 (dì). This character is simply placed in front of the number:

Chinese English 第 一dì-yīThe first 第 二dì-èrThe second 第 三dì-sānThe third 第 四dì-sìThe fourth 第 五dì-wǔThe fifth 第 六dì-liùThe sixth 第 七dì-qīThe seventh 第 八dì-bāThe eighth 第 九dì-jiǔThe ninth 第 十dì-shíThe tenth
Full Pattern with Measure Words
You can also add in a measure word and a noun to make the structure a bit fuller.

children.english: I'm the first person that came to the office.
He needs to take the first train in the morning to go to work.
Little Li is her third boyfriend.
My first Chinese teacher was American.
Dad‘s first cell phone was a  Nokia.
What was your first job?
I found a job the second month I was in the USA.
How do you read the fifth character from the second line?
On this test, I was first in our class.
In this contest, our class is the first, their class is the second.

blocks.html: Note that there are some words that don't use measure words because they themselves are already measure words. For example: 天 (tiān), 年 (nián), 周 (zhōu), 次 (cì), etc.

children.english: On the first day, we will be in the hotel.
He started this company his second year after coming to Shanghai.
The boss needs to go on a business trip the first week of next month.
This is my first time going to Beijing.

blocks.html: Note that some nouns can form ordinals without 第 (dì). With these, the number can be used directly. For example, 七楼 (qī lóu) is "the seventh floor," even though there is no 第 (dì).

You may know that 怎么 (zěnme) can mean "how", but by adding to it and making it 怎么样 (zěnmeyàng), you can ask how something is, or what it is like. This is useful in all manner of conversations, and is essential for building conversation skills.
This question form is super simple. It is similar to asking  the question, "how is...?"
Many of these sample sentences are super common in everyday life, so it's a good idea to get familiar with them.

children.english: How have you been recently?
How is China?
How is Beijing in the winter?
How is the weather today?
How is your little sister's job going?
How's your new phone?
How is the food here? Is it good?

blocks.html: In this pattern,  you're directly asking for an opinion in an open-ended way.

blocks.text: 你 觉得 + Topic + 怎么样 ?

blocks.html: This is like asking, "what do you think of...?"

children.english: What do you think of Shanghai?
What do you think of me?
What do you think of Chinese? Is it difficult to learn?

Aside from just meaning "how," 怎么 (zěnme) can also be used to ask "why" or "how come."
Similar to the question word 为什么 (wèishénme), questions can also be asked with 怎么 (zěnme).
This has similar connotations to saying "how come" in English. It not only asks why, but expresses some surprise at the situation, and in some cases even disagreement with it.

children.english: How come he's not here yet?
How can you hit people?
He helped you. How come you didn't say thank you?
How come you didn't tell me when you got married?
We haven't started eating yet. How come he has already finished eating?
Today is Monday. Why aren't you going to work?

blocks.html: In this case,  it's most common to negate the adjective after 怎么 (zěnme).

children.english: Why is the water not hot?
Why is the Sichuan food here not spicy?
He kissed you. How come you're not happy?
Her kitten died. Why isn't she sad?
Every day you work 12 hours. Why are you not tired?

blocks.html: One pattern this use of 怎么 (zěnme) frequently appears in is with 这么 (zhème) or 那么 (nàme). (For more on 这么 (zhème) and 那么 (nàme), see adjectives with "name" and "zheme.")

blocks.text: Subj. + 怎么 + 这么 / 那么 + Adj.

blocks.html: This use of 怎么 (zěnme) could be translated as either "how" or "why"; the actual meaning sort of falls in the fuzzy region between the two. In any case, it's used to express disbelief: how can (something) be so (adjective)?!

children.english: How can he be this lazy?
How could it be so cold yesterday?
How can these people so loud?
How can the air in Beijing be so bad?
How is your Mandarin so good?

Asking questions about completed actions will involve using both 了 (le) and 吗 (ma). These are simply added to the end of a sentence or statement. Just make sure that 了 (le) comes first, followed by 吗 (ma).
Note the order of 了 (le) and 吗 (ma).

Did the boss leave?
Has your boyfriend found a new job yet?
Mom, did you call me yesterday?
Did you go to work today?

children.english: Did you eat dinner?
Have you finished washing the clothes?
Have you finishing doing homework?
Have you seen this movie?
Have you received my email?

You will often come across 因为⋯⋯所以⋯⋯ (yīnwèi... suǒyǐ...) in both written and spoken Chinese. This pattern will give your Chinese a clear logical structure, and can help make you more persuasive.
Using 因为 (yīnwèi) by Itself to Explain Causes
blocks.text: Using 因为 (yīnwèi) by Itself to Explain Causes

blocks.html: A common way to explain causes in Chinese is with 因为 (yīnwèi). This is equivalent to "because" in English. Usually 因为 (yīnwèi) will begin a new phrase in a sentence.
In this structure, we first state the result, and then give the reason in the next statement after the 因为 (yīnwèi).

children.english: He learns fast because he is smart.
I love eating Sichuan food because it's very spicy.
I am studying Chinese because I want to go to China.
I don't like her because she is very unfriendly.
We are very busy today because we have lots of work.

blocks.html: Using 所以 (suǒyǐ) by Itself to Explain Results
blocks.text: Using 所以 (suǒyǐ) by Itself to Explain Results

blocks.html: Just as 因为 (yīnwèi) can be used to explain causes, 所以 (suǒyǐ) can be used to explain results. This is the equivalent of "so…" or "therefore…" in English.
This pattern is similar to the expression using both 因为 (yīnwèi) and 所以 (suǒyǐ), but it leaves out the beginning 因为 (yīnwèi). This structure is more informal.

children.english: Chinese characters are too hard, so I don't want to study them.
She is beautiful, so a lot of boys like her.
He found a job so he's happy.
I was too busy, so I didn't have time to give you a call.
There are a lot of foreigners in our company, so we need to speak English.

blocks.html: Using 因为 (yīnwèi) and 所以 (suǒyǐ) Together
blocks.text: Using 因为 (yīnwèi) and 所以 (suǒyǐ) Together

blocks.html: The full pattern 因为……所以…… (yīnwèi... suǒyǐ...) is used to clearly indicate cause and effect. They could be thought of as equating to: "Since ___ happened, so ___ happened." It sounds weird to use both "since" and "so" in one sentence in English, but it makes everything crystal clear in Chinese.

blocks.text: 因为 + Cause, 所以 + Effect

blocks.html: This expresses that because of cause, therefore there is a result.

children.english: Since I have a Chinese girlfriend, I need to study Chinese.
Since he was sick, he didn't go to class.
I'm very tired, so I want to rest.
Since it's too far, I don't want to go.
We were too busy, so none of us had time to eat lunch.

blocks.html: Remember that 了 (le) is not only for the past! When something is about to happen, you can also indicate this using 了 (le). Normally it is paired with a 快 (kuài), 快要(kuàiyào) or a 要 (yào). This is a special form of using 了 to indicate a change of situation.
快⋯⋯了 (kuài... le) with Verbs
When using 快 ⋯⋯了 (kuài... le) with verbs, it takes on a meaning similar to the English "just about to." Normally you can add 要 (yào) before the verb.

children.english: We're almost there.
It's going to rain soon.
It's almost Chinese New Year. When are you going back to your hometown?
My girlfriend is about to have her birthday.
We're about to get off. Just wait a little while.

blocks.html: Notice that for some translations, it's more natural to use the English word "almost" instead of "soon."
快⋯⋯了 (kuài... le) with Adjectives
In this structure, 快⋯⋯了 (kuài... le) is closer to the meaning of "almost" in English.

children.english: It’s almost getting dark.
I'm almost ready.
The food is about to be cold.
These dirty clothes are about to smell bad.
I can't drink another, I am almost drunk.

blocks.html: 要⋯⋯了 (yào... le) with Verbs
You can also just use 要 (yào) before the verb, without 快 (kuài).

blocks.text: Subj. + 要 + Verb / Adj. + 了

blocks.html: Note that occasionally you'll see adjectives (instead of verbs) in this pattern as well.

children.english: I'm going to get angry!
Their child is about to be born.
It's 9 o'clock. The supermarket is about to close.
My best friend is about to get married!
It's almost Christmas. What plans do you have?

blocks.html: 什么……都 (shénme... dōu) is a pattern often used to express "all" or "everything." Because it's not just one word, though, it can be a little tricky to get the hang of at first.
In this structure, 都 (dōu) is more frequently used than 也 (yě)。

blocks.text: Topic (+ Subj.) + 什么 + 都 / 也 + Verb / Adj.

blocks.html: In some sentences, there will be a subject after the topic in the pattern above. See the following sentences for examples.
When used in the positive sense, it is more natural to follow 什么 (shénme) with 都 (dōu) rather than 也 (yě) to express "everything."

children.english: I think everything is delicious here.
My dad knows everything about Chinese history.
My husband tells me everything about work stuff.
I like everything that mom cooks.
My  girlfriend thinks that all foreign things are good.
We drink any kind of fruit juice.
All of her clothes are black.
All of the dishes mom makes are tasty.
My boyfriend likes all kinds of sports.
You shouldn't tell him everything.

blocks.html: The negative structure simply adds a 不 (bù) or a 没 (méi) after the 都 (dōu) / 也 (yě).  Instead of "all" or "everything," this expresses "none" or "not any."

blocks.text: 什么 + Noun + 都 / 也 + 不 + Verb
什么 + Noun + 都 / 也 + 没 (有) + Verb

children.english: After dad got sick, he can't drink any kind of alcohol.
The boss is very angry. He's doesn't want to see anybody.
Today I don't feel well, so I didn't eat anything.
She didn't say anything at yesterday's meeting.
How  come you haven't done anything at home?

title: Expressing location with "zai... shang / xia / li"
pattern: 在 + Place + 上 / 下 / 里 / 旁边

blocks.html: You can use 在 (zài) to express location, but this article will explain how to use 在 (zài) to express location in relation to another object. This way, you can describe if something is "on the table" or "in the room."
If you're talking about a "big place," like a country or city, then all you need is 在 (zài) and the name of the place.
For example, these phrases are fine just as they are:

children.english: in China
in the USA
in Shanghai
in New York

blocks.html: You wouldn't want to add other words to the ends of these place names.
To show where an object is in relation to another object, make a "sandwich" starting with 在 (zài), add a place, and then add one of the following words: 上 (shàng), 下 (xià), 里 (lǐ), 旁边 (pángbiān).

blocks.text: 在 + Location+ 上 / 下 / 里 / 旁边

blocks.html: Notice that the "preposition" comes after the location and object that it modifies. That is, in English we say "on the table," but in Chinese, it is more like "at the table, on." This can be somewhat confusing, but don't worry. Once you start using this construction, it gets easy really quickly.

children.english: on the table
on the floor.
Is your cell phone in the bag?
He is downstairs.
Walmart is next to my house.
I am on the train.
I'm on the metro.
in class
at the party
at the meeting
at the wedding

blocks.html: The little words that come after the location in the phrases above aren't really "prepositions." They are called "nouns of locality," or 方位词 (fāngwèicí) in Chinese.  They actually tend to have several forms, which can be confusing if you're not used to them.  The chart below shows their most common forms:

One-Character Two-Character English 上shàng上面 / 上边shàngmiàn / shàngbiantop, above 下xià下面 / 下边xiàmiàn / xiàbianbottom, under 里lǐ里面 / 里边lǐmiàn / lǐbianinside 外wài外面 / 外边wàimiàn / wàibian outside 边biān旁边pángbiānside, beside 前qián前面 / 前边qiánmiàn / qiánbian front 后hòu后面 / 后边hòumiàn / hòubianback, behind 左zuǒ左边zuǒbianleft 右yòu右边yòubianright

Some prepositions can be paired with more abstract concepts to form idiomatic phrases. These kinds of phrases can really make your Chinese sound polished. Later on you will learn about these idiomatic phrases with "zai".

blocks.html: You may know how to make negative commands with "bie," but what if someone is already doing it? The pattern 别⋯⋯了 (bié... le) is all you need to tell someone to STOP DOING THAT (which they're already doing).
Instead of just a verb, it can also be a verb phrase.

children.english: Stop talking. I don't want to listen.
Stop asking. I don't want to say.
Stop doing it. Do it tomorrow.
Stop watching. Go to sleep!
Stop crying!
Stop laughing. Other people are looking at you.
Stop eating. We're going to be late.
Stop playing. Do your homework.
Stop drinking. You're already drunk.

blocks.html:
The "别 verb 了“ pattern can also be used to negate the other person's suggestion or try to change their idea. The difference between this usage and the previous example is that the action has not happened yet. 
A few examples:

children.explanation: In this case, the person probably isn't actually paying, but she or he is thinking about it.
children.english: Don't buy it. It's too expensive!

children.explanation: In this case, the person probably isn't actually cooking, but she or he is thinking about it.
children.english: Let's go out for dinner instead of cook.

children.explanation: In this case, the person hasn't left yet, but she or he is thinking about going out.
children.english: It's raining. Let's stay inside instead of going out.

Both 不 (bù) and 没 (méi) can be placed in front of a verb or adjective to negate its meaning. However, 不 (bù) and 没 (méi) are not usually interchangeable, so it's important to learn when you must use 不 (bù) as opposed to 没 (méi), and vice versa.
不 (bù) Negates in the Present and Future
blocks.text: 不 (bù) Negates in the Present and Future

blocks.html: 不 (bù) is generally used to negate an action that you do not want to do or do not intend to do (in the future). So expressing things like "I don't want to go" or "I'm not going" would be uses of 不 (bù).
Whether it's "don't wanna do it"  or "not gonna do it," use 不 (bù):

children.english: Tonight I'm not going to drink.
Dad is not coming back to eat dinner.
The boss won't come tomorrow.
I know it's not going to rain this weekend.
Is your girlfriend not going with you?

blocks.html: 不 (bù) can be used to negate habitual actions, to express what you just aren't in the habit of doing, such as eating meat, or watching TV, or drinking alcohol.  This is simply done by placing 不 (bù) in front of the verb.

children.english: I don't eat meat.
Do you all not drink alcohol?
He doesn't like to speak.
Do you not use your phone to read books?
Don't you shower at night?

blocks.html: Please note that, while it is grammatically correct to use 没 (méi) in all the sentences above, 没 (méi) does not negate any habitual actions. The sentences above, if they contained 没 (méi) instead of 不 (bù), would express that the speaker didn't do the named activity (at one particular point in the past). So it would not be about habitual actions.
不 (bù) Is Normally Used with Adjectives
blocks.text: 不 (bù) Is Normally Used with Adjectives

blocks.html: When it comes to a simple negation of an adjective (such as "not cold"), use 不 (bù).

children.english: We're not hungry.
You are not fat.
My home is not far.
Today it isn't cold.
I think the coffee at Starbucks isn't good.

blocks.html: 不 (bù) Is for Asking Questions

There are couple ways to use 不 (bù) to ask questions. One such way is through affirmative-negative questions. This is done by stating a verb and then immediately repeating that verb in a negative state (with 不 (bù)).

children.english: Are you my teacher or not?
Does she want to come?
Do you love me or not?
Do you all go to work on weekends?
Do your foreign friends like to eat Chinese food?

blocks.html: 不 (bù) can also be used to form tag questions. Tag questions use the positive-negative question form, but are placed at the end of the sentence. Tag questions are used to seek approval or acceptance for a statement, very similar to the English "OK?" or "right?" You can't use 没 (méi) for this.

children.english: Let's go eat, is that OK?
You are good friends, right?

blocks.html: 没 (méi) and 没有 (méiyǒu) can both be used to negate actions that occurred in the past, or to say that something has not happened yet.

children.english: He did not give me a call.
You didn't go to work?
I did not drink alcohol yesterday.
Mom did not cook dinner.
They didn't pay after they finished eating.
I not drink wine yesterday.
I not meet with him last weekend.
You not go to Beijing last month?

blocks.html: There are a few things worth noting in these examples. For one, it is still grammatically correct to leave out the 有 (yǒu) in the sentences using 没有 (méiyǒu). Also, the sentences using 不 (bù) would be grammatically correct, if not for the time words telling us that it is definitely the past we're talking about.
Only 没 (méi) Negates 有 (yǒu)
没 (méi) can be used to negate the verb 有 (yǒu) ("to have") to mean "do not have." You can only use 没 (méi) to convey this meaning. It is grammatically incorrect to use 不 (bù) to negate 有 (yǒu).

children.english: I don't have money.
He doesn't have a girlfriend.

blocks.html: There are times when you can leave out 有 (yǒu) entirely while still expressing 没有 (méiyǒu), (meaning "to not have" or "there is no"). One well-known example of this is 没办法 (méi bànfǎ) ("there is no way" [that's gonna happen]). Both 没 (méi) and 没有 (méiyǒu) are correct, however.

children.english: I don't have a way.
I don't have a way.

blocks.html: (You can also use 没办法 (méi bànfǎ) to express other meanings.)
没 (méi) Is for Making Comparisons
没 (méi) or 没有 (méiyǒu) can be used to make simple comparisons meaning "not as... as...":

children.english: You are not as tall as me.
My cell phone isn't as expensive as his.
We all are not as busy as the boss.
Shanghai winters are not as cold Beijing winters.

blocks.html: You can only use 没 (méi) or 没有 (méiyǒu) for this purpose, and not 不 (bù).
不 (bù) Is Used Almost Exclusively with Certain Verbs
blocks.text: 不 (bù) Is Used Almost Exclusively with Certain Verbs

blocks.html: Certain verbs just don't get negated by 没 (méi) or 没有 (méiyǒu) ever.  These include the verbs 是 (shì) ("to be") and 在 (zài) ("to be (in a place)"), as well as some psychological verbs such as 知道 (zhīdào) ("to know") and 认识 (rènshi) ("to know (a person)").  For these verbs, it's best to just take them on a case-by-case basis.  Being aware of their existence can save you a fair bit of confusion.

children.english: He was not my boss before.
I didn't know he was coming.
He did not know her when he was young.

children.explanation: Use of 没 with 在 is technically incorrect, but you sometimes hear it.

children.english: I was not home yesterday.

blocks.html: Note that in non-standard Mandarin you might encounter exceptions to this rule.  It's still useful to know the rule!

Both 要 (yào) and 想 (xiǎng) can essentially mean "want," but they can also be used in quite different ways, such as 想 (xiǎng) also meaning "to miss" when followed by a noun, and 要 (yào) also meaning "going to (do something)."
Both 要 (yào) and 想 (xiǎng) may be followed by nouns, but pay attention to how the meaning of 想 (xiǎng) totally changes when used this way.
In this pattern, 要 (yào) is directly followed by a thing (a noun), rather than by a verb. It is often used to buy something, or to order food at a restaurant.

It may be helpful to imagine a demanding child using this pattern to get stuff from his parents. This "I want x!" pattern can seem slightly impolite, but to the Chinese ear it's not as inherently rude as it may seem when translated directly into English. Tone of voice plays a key role when using this pattern in spoken Chinese.

children.english: Do you also want tea?
We all want coffee.
Does everyone want rice?
Do you want ice water or hot water?
Thank you. I don't need anything.

blocks.html: Pay attention here: unlike "想 (xiǎng) + Verb," the meaning of 想 (xiǎng) in the "想 (xiǎng) + Noun" pattern becomes "to miss."

children.english: I miss you.
I sort of miss my family.
Will you all miss Chinese food after you go back to the U.S.?
Do you miss your girlfriend when she is not around?
Mom called me and said she misses me a lot.

blocks.html: 要 (yào) and 想 (xiǎng) have similar meanings when followed by verbs. The difference is rather subtle, but 要 (yào) can sound more urgent or demanding (sometimes even childish), while 想 (xiǎng) is usually a bit more mature and polite. Tone of voice plays a big role here as well, though, so don't be afraid of offending people by using 要 (yào); the word itself isn't rude.
It might help to think of 要 (yào) in this sense as meaning "want to" and 想 (xiǎng) as meaning "would like to."

children.english: I want to rest.
Do you also want to go home?
What do you want to drink?
I want to help the boss finish this work.
Does everyone want to go out to eat tonight?

blocks.html: It might help to think of 想 (xiǎng) as meaning "would like to" instead of "want to." In English, as well, "would like to" feels more indirect, and thus less demanding and more more polite.

children.english: Would you like to go?
I wouldn't like to see her.
Would you like to see a movie this weekend?
I'd like to treat you to dinner.
Don't they want to go back home for Spring Festival?

blocks.html: 要 is used to indicate plans for the near future, much like "going to" in English. 想 (xiǎng) is not used in this way.

children.english: I'm going to Beijing on Saturday.
She is going to look for a new job next month.
Are you going out partying this weekend?
Are you going to live together with your parents after you get married?
Is your wife going back to work after she finishes giving birth to the baby?

blocks.html: You can put 要 (yào) and 想 (xiǎng) together to make the word 想要 (xiǎngyào), which means "to want." You can put either nouns or verbs after it.

children.english: How many kids do you want to have?
My wife always wants the most expensive bags.
She wants to find a rich boyfriend.
Why do you all want to leave Beijing?
He wants to help you find a better job.
